input: M: Do you mind if I smoke here? W: Sorry, not here. Go ahead at the comer, please.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) Please smoke over there. (B) Just smoke here. (C) You can't smoke anywhere.

input: W: Do you think we have to review the history of the American Civil War? M: Without a doubt, it'll be on the exam.
target: What does the man mean? (A) They'll see a film about the American Civil War. (B) He did poorly in his history exam. (C) They will be tested on the American Civil War.

input: F: Who broken the window, Tom? M: It was the ball, Mum. I threw the ball to Mary, but she missed it.
target: What is true according to the dialog? (A) The window is repaired. (B) The ball is lost. (C) Tom played with Mary just now.

input: W: Yesterday I met Mike in the street. M: It's impossible. He left for London the day before yesterday and hasn't come back yet.
target: What are they probably talking about? (A) A man (B) A book (C) A building

input: M: Excuse me. Where would I find medicine for dogs? W: We have some on aisle five. If you need a wider selection, however, I would suggest going to see an animal doctor.
target: What does the man want to do? (A) Find an animal doctor. (B) Buy medicine for dogs. (C) Let the woman check his dogs.

input: M: How much is the note book? W: Three yuan for one, five yuan for two and seven yuan for three. M: Then. I'll take three.
target: How much should the man pay? (A) Three yuan. (B) Five yuan. (C) Seven yuan.

input: W: Bill, have you finished the research paper for biology? M: Not yet. I always seem to put things off until the last minute.
target: What did the man mean? (A) He never does assignments early. (B) He'll finish it in a few minutes. (C) He wrote it last semester.

input: M: Let's try to find seats near the stage. W: Listen, we'll be lucky if we can find a place to stand at the concert.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) They prefer to stand. (B) They can't find seat. (C) They can sit near the stage.

input: M: The Dean just announced that Dr. Holden's going. I'll miss you guys while I'm working here in the library. W: I knew it all along! He's the obvious choice. All the other candidates are no match for him!
target: What do we learn about the two speakers? (A) The dean should have consulted her on the appointment. (B) Dr. Holden should have taken over the position earlier. (C) Dr. Holden is the best person for the chairmanship.

input: M: Did it cost very much to stay overnight in the hotel? W: More than you would believe.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) the cost was reasonable (B) the cost was unbelievably high (C) she likes the hotel

input: W: I'll send Jane a new American stamp. M: I'm sure she'd be pleased to get it. She has a collection of stamps from foreign counties.
target: What do we learn about Jane? (A) She's going to America. (B) She has travelled abroad. (C) She likes collecting stamps.

input: M: What a terrible story! A couple was sailing their boat from Hawaii to Mexico. While they were crossing the Pacific, their boat hit a whale and sank! W: Is that true? What happened to the whale? M: It doesn't say. Oh, and here's another one. A guy in Los Angeles was robbing a bank. But as he was escaping, he got caught in the revolving door. W: I guess it was his first bank robbery! M: Yeah. Oh, and listen to this. Some guy got locked out of his house, so he tried to get in through the chimney. W: Don't tell me! He got stuck in the chimney! M: Exactly. And he was still trying to get out two days later when the police rescued him.
target: How many stories did the man tell the woman? (A) Two. (B) Three. (C) Four.

input: M: Hi, Natasha. I see you're going out for a run. You don't have to go to work today? W: I've started running to work instead of taking the bus. It's good for the environment. M: I drive to work. I keep fit at the gym. W: Well, running gives me a wonderful feeling of freedom-it's just what I need before sitting down in the office every day. M: Are you going to join in the big race next month? W: I'd like to. Are you going to take part in it? M: Oh, yes. But I'm not going to train by running to work. I'll run around the park a few times when I get home in the evenings. W: OK. Anyway I must go now or I'll be late. Bye.
target: How does the woman go to work? (A) By car. (B) By running. (C) By bus.

input: M: I exhausted I stayed up the whole night studying for my middle term matches exam. W: But why do you always wait until the last minute?
target: What does the woman imply? (A) The man is a diligent student. (B) The man has bad study habits. (C) The man has made a mess of his midtermexam.

input: W: Do you watch sports programs on weekend? M: No. I enjoy meeting friends at weekends.
target: How often does the man watch sports programs on weekend? (A) Once a week. (B) Never. (C) Once a month.

input: W: I'd like to book four tickets to Shanghai on November 28th. M: Would you want one-way or round-trip? W: Round-trip. We will return on December 10th, oh, no, sorry, 12th. M: Yes, four tickets on November 28th to Shanghai and returning on December 12th.
target: When will the woman return? (A) On November 28. (B) On December 10. (C) On December 12.

input: M: Any message for me, Miss White? W: Just one, Mr. Brown. You had a phone call from someone called Smith, Mary Smith. M: Smith? I don't know anyone called Smith. What did she say? W: She wouldn't say anything. But it sounded important. I told her you'd call her as soon as you came back. M: Well, I think I'd better do it then. Have you got her telephone number? W: Yes, it's 44356793. M: Have you written it down? W: I always do. It's on your desk. M: Thank you.
target: Who made the telephone call? (A) Miss Smith. (B) Miss White. (C) Mr. Brown.

input: W: What are some of the problems of doing a part-time job as a college student? M: Schoolwork suffers. Because I don't have as much time to study as when I didn't have a part-time job. I have had to give up things I enjoy, like sleep and football. I can't get into the social life because I have to work right after class. Some of my Mends have stopped calling me. I also miss TV. W: What do you do in a day? M: I get up at seven to make an 8:00 a. m. class. I have classes till 1:30. And then, I drive to the supermarket where I work. I work till 7:00 p. m. And then I drive to my home and eat dinner. After I take a shower and rest for a half hour, it's about nine. This gives me only a couple of hours to study. My eyes start to close well before I go to bed at eleven.
target: What does the man usually do in the morning? (A) Watch TV. (B) Have classes. (C) Play football.

input: W: Do you think that Jim really fell in love with Alison? M: Of course! I've never seen him spend so much time and energy on the same person.
target: What can we learn from the conversation? (A) Alison fell in love with Jim. (B) Jim fell in love with Alison. (C) Jim wasted a lost of time.

input: W: Peter, how is the weather now? Is it still raining? M: No, but there's still lots of clouds. The weatherman said the sun wouldn't come out until next week.
target: What is the weather like now? (A) It's sunny. (B) It's rainy. (C) It's cloudy.

input: F: I'm afraid I can't remember you. M: I'm Mike. Mary, your classmate, is my friend. Don't you remember we met each other at an evening party?
target: When did they meet the first time? (A) One evening. (B) One morning. (C) In the evening.

input: W: When shall I come again? M: Well, I'm afraid we must wait till all the applications are in and if we decide to put your name on our short list, we'll let you know.
target: The woman is supposed to be a (n) ________. (A) shop assistant (B) job applicant (C) interviewer

input: M: Have you finished reading the book you bought last month? W: Oh, I didn't read straight through the way you read a novel, I just covered a few chapters which interested me most.
target: How did the woman read the book? (A) She read it selectively. (B) She went over it chapter by chapter. (C) She read it slowly.

input: M: How is the weather today? W: It's very cold and wet. M: Are the winters like this every year in this place? W: Pretty much. But it was a little colder last year. M: Now I know why people here have thick clothes on. W: What is the weather like in winter in your country? M: It's quite different from yours. It's warm and hot in my hometown all year round. W: You are very lucky then. M: Well, some people in my country want to have your weather.
target: What is the weather like in winter in the woman's place? (A) Cold and wet. (B) Cold and dry. (C) Warm and hot.

input: W: There isn't any fish here. There's some beef. Would you like some? M: No, thanks.
target: What is there in the shop? (A) Fish. (B) Meat. (C) Beef.

input: M: Did you have a good vacation, Katie? W: Yeah! It was exciting-probably my most exciting vacation ever! M: Wow! What did you do? W: I took a nature adventure tour. For the first part, we went hiking. It was so much fun! We hiked all the way up to those beautiful waterfalls. I took lots of pictures. M: Sounds great. So, what else did you do on the tour? W: Well, the best part was at the end of the trip. We went skydiving! Can you believe it? I jumped out of an airplane. M: Wow! W: Yeah, it was just a fantastic vacation. How did you spend your break, Ryan? M: Oh, I drove to visit my relatives. W: Uh-huh. Did you have a good time? M: Well, it was pretty boring, actually. It rained every day so we had to stay inside. We just stayed at home and watched TV a lot. W: Oh, that's too bad. M: No, that's OK. It really was very relaxing, even though it was a little boring.
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) Adventure. (B) Vacation. (C) Weather.

input: M: The bus is always late. W: I know. I've been waiting for it for half an hour. If it doesn't come in another 15 minutes, I'll go on foot.
target: How much longer will the woman wait for the bus? (A) 45 minutes. (B) 30 minutes. (C) 15 minutes.

input: W: Bob, I'm sure you know about second-hand smoke. M: Of course, I do. W: But have you heard about third-hand smoke? M: Third-hand smoke? I'm afraid not. What is that then? W: Well, it is here in today's paper. Parents may think they are protecting children from second-hand smoke when they smoke outside their home or only when the children are not there. But now researchers are warning about what they call third-hand smoke. When you smoke dangerous matter from cigarettes get into your hair and clothing. As babies are the weakest, when you come to a baby, you pass it to the baby and increase the chances of disease in the baby. M: Is that so? In that case I have to say that I should never get close to a baby. W: That's right. Actually all smoking parents should do the same or better give it up completely.
target: How did the woman get to know about third-hand smoke? (A) From young smokers. (B) From a newspaper article. (C) From some smoking parents.

input: M: I'm going to the shops in a minute. What do we need? W: We are ok for the vegetables and meat, but we need some bread. Can you go and get some? M: No problem. I'll go and get it. W: Ok, see you later then.
target: What will the man buy? (A) Vegetable (B) Meat (C) Bread

input: W: Is the flight from New York on time? M: Yes, it is. It should be arriving in 30 minutes at Gate 7.
target: Where does the conversation take place? (A) In a hotel. (B) At an airport. (C) In the street.

input: W: Just look at this newspaper, nothing but murder, death and war! Do you still believe people are basically good? M: Of course I do. But newspapers hardly ever report stories about peace and generosity. They are not news.
target: What do we learn from the conversation? (A) The man is quite optimistic about human nature. (B) The woman is unsure if there will be peace in the world. (C) The woman is doubtful about newspaper stories.

input: W: Excuse me. I wonder if you could tell me how to find a place to have my shoes mended. I'm new in town. M: Ah, there is a good shop not far from here. Go straight ahead and walk about three blocks. I can't remember the name of the shop, but you'll find it. It's near the police station. By the way, you know about the town guide? It's a thin book and has all kinds of useful information. You'll find one in any bookstore. W: Thanks a lot! You've been so helpful. Let's see. Did you say the repair shop was three blocks away from here? M: Exactly. W: Thanks again.
target: What is the woman looking for? (A) An information office. (B) A police station. (C) A shoe repair shop.

input: W: I really must go now. M: What time is your train? W: 11:20. Oh,dear. It's already 11:00. I'm going to miss my train. M: Don't worry. I'll drive you to the station.
target: What will probably happen to the woman? (A) Miss her train. (B) Catch her train. (C) Cancel her train.

input: W: Have you decided where to go this winter, Harbin or Guangzhou? M: Well, I don't enjoy cold weather at all, but I'll go somewhere.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He will go to Harbin (B) He will stay at home (C) He will go on a trip

input: M: I believe that choosing this man will be a complete mistake. W: I wouldn't look at like that.
target: What is the woman's attitude? (A) She agrees with the man. (B) She doesn't agree with the man. (C) She doesn't know what to do.

input: M: Look at the girl on the bike! F: Oh, yes she's really a smart girl.
target: Where are the two persons? (A) At home (B) In their classroom (C) On the street

input: W: How did you ever move that desk upstairs to your room? M: It was very heavy. But I got my roommates to help me with it.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He and his roommates moved the desk to his room. (B) The desk wasn't as heavy as it looked. (C) His roommates found him another desk.

input: M: From our teacher's appearance. She looks like a European. W: But I think she's an Asian.
target: What does the man think of the teacher? (A) She's from Asia. (B) She's from Africa. (C) She's from Europe.

input: M: How many years of science did you have in high school? W: I had one year each of biology and chemistry. I wish I had had more.
target: How many science courses did the woman take in high school? (A) One. (B) Two. (C) More than two.

input: M: What would you like to drink, tea or coffee? W: Neither. Just a glass of water.
target: What would the woman like to drink? (A) Tea. (B) Coffee. (C) Water.

input: W: How many horses are there under the tree? M: There are three, and there are four cows behind the tree.
target: How many animals can the man see? (A) Seven. (B) Three. (C) Four.

input: M: I'm afraid John's busy at the moment, madam. W: Oh, dear. John always does my hair.
target: What do we know about John? (A) John is a close friend of the woman's. (B) John is the best hairdresser in town. (C) John is a hairdresser.

input: M: We'd better hurry. I think that's our flight. W: Have I got time to get a newspaper? M: Well, I don't think we have time. Look--- W: All right, well, you take that bag, and I'll take this one.
target: Where does this conversation probably take place? (A) At an airport. (B) At a railway station. (C) At a department store.

input: W: Excuse me, I'm trying to get to the courthouse and I think I'm going the wrong way. Should I have turned left on Monroe Street? M: No, no. You're all right. Just keep going straight on Fourth Avenue until you get to the Post Office, and turn left there.
target: Where does the woman want to go? (A) The post office. (B) Monroe Street. (C) The courthouse.

input: M: Let's see now. They can park fifteen cars in that back lot, can't they? W: Oh, didn't you know? They've doubled the capacity.
target: How many cars can be parked in the back lot? (A) A total of 15. (B) A total of 30. (C) A total of 50.

input: M: Do you want to go for a picinc with me tomorrow? W: I'd like to. How about asking Jenny to go with us? M: Oh, no. She is busy with her dancing class. You know, there is a very big performance in just a week. W: Yes, you're right. It is really not good for her to learn dancing. Her leg hasn't completely recovered from that accident. M: But she doesn't think so. She is crazy about dancing. Will you take your camera with you tomorrow? W: I want to, but I lent it to Tom yesterday. Do you have one? M: No, but I know Mary has got one. Let's go and ask her if she'd like to join us. W: OK.
target: What does the man want to do tomorrow? (A) Go for a picnic. (B) Go swimming. (C) Go fishing.

input: M: When did you see the American film? W: I saw it after school.
target: Did the girl see the film during school hours? (A) No. she saw it after school. (B) Yes, she did. (C) She didn't see the film at all.

input: W: Would you mind turning down the radio, Andre? M: Sorry, I didn't know it was bothering you. W: Not me, but the baby in bed.
target: What is the baby doing now? (A) Perhaps the baby is playing. (B) Perhaps the baby is sleeping. (C) Perhaps the baby is listening to the radio.

input: W: The map shows that this street goes downtown. M: Yes, but what we want to know is how to get to the park.
target: What does the man mean? (A) They want to go downtown. (B) He wants to find out where the park is. (C) He wants to go to the park, but she doesn't.

input: W: Look at my bike. I think I should buy a new one. M: Yes, I agree.
target: What did the man want to do? (A) He wanted to buy a bike. (B) He wanted to borrow a bike. (C) He wanted to sell a bike.

input: M: What did your doctor describe for you? W: Well, he said there is no need for me to take any medicine if I eat well-balanced meals.
target: What did the man do last year for his brother's birthday? (A) No medicine could solve the woman's problem. (B) The woman should eat less to lose some weight. (C) The woman should choose the right foods.

input: M: Are you finished with the newspaper, Mary? W: Almost. Here, you can take the news section. And the entertainment section's in the living room. M: Oh, I just want to read the sports section.
target: Which section does the man like to read? (A) News (B) Sport (C) Entertainment

input: W: Jack, are you going to play tennis with us today? M: I promised Bill I'd go swimming with him.
target: What will Jack do? (A) Visit Bill. (B) Play tennis. (C) Go swimming.

input: M: Did you get a letter from your family, Jane? W: Not today. I wrote to them yesterday, so I was not really expecting to hear from them till next week.
target: What do we learn from this conversation? (A) Jane wrote a letter to her family yesterday. (B) Jane is expecting a letter from her family. (C) Jane wrote a 1etter to her family today.

input: M: It's quite clear form my visit, this is a full size, comprehensive university. So why is it still called a college? W: The College of William and Mary is the second oldest institution of higher learning in this country. We have nurtured great minds like Thomas Jefferson and we are proud of our name.
target: What do we learn from this conversation about the College of William and Mary? (A) It has a very long history. (B) It is a private institution. (C) It was founded by Thomas Jefferson.

input: W: Goodbye, John. And please send my regards to your parents. M: Sure I will. Thank you very much. Bye.
target: What did the woman ask the man to do? (A) To give her some presents. (B) To give her his parents. (C) To give her best wishes to his parents.

input: M: It's so hot here. Do you mind my opening the door? F: Go ahead.
target: Was the man allowed to open the door? (A) No, he was refused. (B) Yes, he was permitted. (C) It didn't say.

input: W: Excuse me, can you tell me how to get to the Rainbow Restaurant from here? M: Drive two blocks and turn left. Continue on until you reach Heath Street and turn right. Then turn left at the second stop light. You can't miss it.
target: What should the woman do when she gets to Heath Street? (A) Turn right. (B) Turn left. (C) Drive two blocks.

input: W: What time is your train leaving? M: It leaves at ten. I've got fifty minutes left. W: You'd better hurry, or you won't be able to catch it.
target: What time is it now? (A) 9:10. (B) 9:50. (C) 10:00.

input: W: Hi, Mike. Listen, I'm coming back this afternoon, and I'll take a bus from the railway station. So, you don't need to come and pick me up. M: OK, take care, and see you soon.
target: How will the woman get back from the railway station? (A) By train. (B) By car. (C) By bus.

input: M: Are you tired of driving? W: No, I'm doing fine. M: What did I do with my briefcase? W: Isn't it on the back seat? M: No, I don't see it. All my important papers are in it. W: You may have left it at the hotel. Should we turn around and go hack? M: Well, I guess we ought to go back, if you don't mind. W: I'll turn off at the next road.
target: What are there in the briefcase? (A) Some jewellery. (B) Important papers. (C) Money.

input: M: Daisy was furious yesterday because I lost her notebook. Should I go see her and apologize to her again? W: Well, if I were you, I'd let her cool off a few days before I approach her.
target: What does the woman suggest the man do? (A) Leave Daisy alone for the time being. (B) Go see Daisy immediately. (C) Apologize to Daisy again by phone.

input: F: Dear, could you help me here a minute? I want to put the picture up. M: OK, wily don't you cover the table, and I'll put it up.
target: Who will put the picture up? (A) The woman. (B) The man. (C) The man and the woman.

input: M: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here. W: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again. M: He wore out the pair you bought last month? W: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes. M: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes. W: What's your suggestion? M: Maybe you should buy him a pair of leather shoes. W: Tom doesn't like leather shoes. M: Then, how about sports shoes? They are strong and comfortable. W: It seems that is the only choice. All right. I'll take your suggestion. How about this pair? M: They are good.
target: Where does this talk take place probably? (A) In the street. (B) At a shoes shop. (C) On the bus.

input: M: Hello. 138-2369. W: Hello. Is Anna there? M: No. I'm sorry Anna is out. W: Oh, well, could you please leave Anna a message for me? M: Sure. What is it? W: You know, Anna is coming for tea at my home. Would you ask her to see if she has my French dictionary? If she does, tell her to bring it with her. M: All right. And where are you calling from? W: 136, Rose Street. I'm Anna's friend Jenny.
target: Who is Jenny calling? (A) Anna. (B) The man who answers the phone. (C) Rose.

input: M: What do you think of my new suit? W: Not bad. It reminds me of the one I saw at the new department store last week. Did you get it there? M: No, I got it in that big shopping center. It cost me only $ 150. W: Well, I don't think it's a good bargain.
target: What does the woman think of the man's new suit? (A) It is expensive. (B) It is fashionable. (C) It is a good bargain.

input: W: Have you found anything wrong with my stomach? M: Not yet. I'm still examining. I'll let you know the result next week.
target: What's the probable relationship between the speakers? (A) Boss and secretary. (B) Teacher and student. (C) Doctor and patient.

input: M: Excuse me. Is there a book store near here? W: Yes. It's over there, between the post office and the bank. M: Thank you.
target: Where does the man want to go? (A) The bank. (B) The post office. (C) The bookstore.

input: M: How is Jane and Bill's new house? W: It's really comfortable, but they're tired of having to hear the planes go over their house at all hours. M: I think they'll get used to it soon.
target: Where is Jane and Bill's new house? (A) Near a train station. (B) Near an airport. (C) Near a highway.

input: W: The meeting starts at eight thirty. M: We still have thirty minutes.
target: What time is it now? (A) It's eight o'clock. (B) It's eight thirty. (C) It's nine forty.

input: W: Let's look at the survey on consumer confidence we conducted last week. How reliable are these figures? M: They have a 5% margin of error
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) Newly-launched products. (B) Consumer preferences. (C) Survey results.

input: M: I want to go to London. W: A round trip ticket would be cheaper. I can also arrange hotel reservations and guided tour, if you'd like. M: A round trip ticket, please.
target: Where is the man going? (A) London. (B) Beijing. (C) Paris.

input: W: I need to get in touch with Microsoft. I'm having problems with the software Do you know its website? M: Yeah. It's www.microsoft.com. W: Do you think they will take care of my problems? M: Of course they will. The aftersales service is very important to the survival of a company.
target: What does the woman want from Microsoft? (A) She needs them to help her resolve some software problems. (B) She doesn't know its website. (C) She needs them to take care of her.

input: W: Tom, I hear your father has gone to Toronto. Is that right? M: Yes, he'll stay there for more than two months. He'll return at the end of March.
target: In which month did Tom's father go to Toronto? (A) January. (B) February. (C) March.

input: W: You know, I keep forgetting to thank you for sending me flowers when I was itl the hospital. M: Oh, it was nothing. W: It was very kind of you. M: My pleasure.
target: Why did the woman thank the man? (A) Because he sent her to the hospital. (B) Because he sent her some flowers. (C) Because he never forgot to meet her.

input: M: Did Henry paint the whole house himself? W: He had it painted, because he doesn't like climbing ladders.
target: What do we learn from the conversation? (A) Henry doesn't like the color. (B) Someone else painted the house. (C) There was no ladder in the house.

input: W: I heard about your promotion, you must be thrilled. M: Not really, the new office is huge, but the workload has doubled.
target: What do we learn about the man from the conversation? (A) He is pleased with his exciting new job. (B) He finds the huge workload unbearable. (C) He is not so excited about his new position.

input: W: I've got to have my bike repaired. It's very old. I've used it for seven years. M: Why not just buy a new one?
target: What does the man mean? (A) The old bike isn't worth repairing. (B) He can repair the bike for her. (C) The new bike is very cheap.

input: M: Are you ready for the trip to the "Big Apple"? W: "Big Apple"? What do you mean? M: "Big Apple" is the nickname for New York City. Are you going to New York with us, or aren't you? W: Yes, I'm going. I'm especially looking forward to visiting a special show on modern American painters there. But tell me, where did the nickname come from? M: Some of the musicians of the 20s gave it the name. When they played a concert in New York in the 1920s, the musicians called it the "Big Apple". W: Amazing. New York is such an interesting place and it even has an interesting nickname.
target: Who gave the nickname "Big Apple" to New York City? (A) Some painters. (B) Some musicians. (C) Some people visiting New York.

input: M: I hear that the Edwards are thinking of buying another house. W: Should they be doing that with all the other expenses they have to pay? Anyhow, they are over 70 now, their present house is not too bad.
target: What does the man imply? (A) The Edwards are quite well-off. (B) The Edwards should cut down on their living expenses. (C) It'll be unwise for the Edwards to buy another house.

input: M: Well, Sally. Why do you look unhappy? W: Oh, Hill, I have just had a quarrel with Mr. Smith. M: What on earth was it about? W: Well, I have made three bad mistakes so far this week, so he got very angry with me. M: But I don't understand. You are usually very careful and never make mistakes. W: I'm just so tired. I don't know what I'm doing. M: Why? Have you been going to bed late these days? W: No, I'm usually in bed at about eleven. But I've been woken up at about half past four every morning. And then I cannot go back to sleep again, M: Why? W: It's my new neighbor, the milkman next door. He gets up at half past four and he always turns the radio on loudly. And it's difficult to ask him to mm it down. I don't know him yet. M: If you don't want to see him, write him a letter. I'll help you write the letter. W: OK. Let's try.
target: Why was Sally unhappy? (A) She could not sleep at night. (B) She could not talk to the milkman. (C) She had quarrelled with Mr. Smith.

input: M: Would you like to go to a party tonight? W: That sounds like a good idea. M: Would 7:00 be OK? W: That's fine. I'm looking forward to it.
target: What will the speakers do over tonight? (A) Go to a party. (B) Stay at home. (C) Climb mountains.

input: W: The strike of the porters has hold up export orders for two weeks. Do you think it will end soon? M: So far as I know, the management side has made an improved pay offer but the unions are just holding out for the original demands.
target: What does the man think of the strike? (A) It will last for two weeks. (B) It has come to a halt. (C) It will probably continue.

input: M: I can't believe I passed the final on urban planning! That is the subject I hated the most last semester. W: Yeah, and what's more ironic is you seldom attended the lectures.
target: What does the woman think? (A) The results of her finals are ironic. (B) The result of the final is unbelievable. (C) The man should have attended the lectures.

input: M: Is this desk available? I need to find some work space. W: Let me think. That's Terry's spot but I think he's working from home today. M: That's where Terry sits? Then I can't work there. I just saw him in the parking lot. W: Oh, that's right. Terry's working from home on Monday and Wednesday this week - his schedule's always changing and I can never keep track of it. But why don't you try over where Gordon sits? There's an extra desk over there.
target: What is the relationship between the speakers? (A) Classmates. (B) Workmates. (C) Husband and wife.

input: W: The admission price of the gallery is ten dollars per person. I think that's too expensive for a single exhibit. M: But if we have student cards, we can get in for two. W: Really? Let's have a try.
target: Where are the man and the woman probably talking? (A) Outside an art museum. (B) Inside a bookstore. (C) In the restaurant.

input: F: What color are these flowers? M: They are yellow.
target: What color are these flowers? (A) Red (B) Yellow (C) Blue

input: M: Today's the last day that Harry Potter is on. We planned to go and see it after school. W: I'd love to, but Professor Brian wants to speak with me.
target: What will the woman probably do? (A) See the movie with the man. (B) See Professor Brian. (C) See Harry Potter.

input: M: I'm both excited and nervous about the job interview this afternoon. W: Take it easy, just wear a tidy and clean clothes and response truthfully to the inquiries and remember, honesty is the best policy.
target: What do we learn about the man? (A) He is nervous about the exam. (B) He is looking for a job. (C) He doesn't dare to tell lies.

input: M: Look at them! They've the latest Adidas shoes. W: You've already had a pair of shoes. M: They cost only $100. W: $1007 For a pair of shoes? M: But they are the latest. I just want to get them. There is a match next week. Oh, Mum, please! W: Ok, this is the last time.
target: What's the relationship of the two people? (A) Teacher and student. (B) Father and son. (C) Mother and son.

input: W: Are you busy on Friday night, Jack? M: Well ... uh ... I haven't got any definite plans yet. Why?
target: What does the man mean? (A) He wants to know the woman's plan. (B) He has a meeting on Friday. (C) He wants to go to the cinema.

input: W: Will you take part in the football match Saturday? M: That's the day after tomorrow. I'm afraid not. I have to set aside three days to prepare for the math exam next week.
target: What day is it today? (A) Sunday. (B) Saturday. (C) Thursday.

input: M: Air pollution is so bad in this city. I think the government should stop people from driving cars on certain days. W: You have a point. Air pollution is a problem. But not letting people drive on certain days is a bad idea. People have to go to work by car. M: I'm afraid I don't agree with you there. Reducing air pollution is really important. People are so used to driving that they don't think about ways to do things. If we stop them from driving on certain days, maybe they could think of new ways to get around. W: I see your point. But I still think it wouldn't be possible to stop people from driving.
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) A way to improve air quality. (B) A problem with traffic rules. (C) A suggestion for city planning.

input: W: Let's talk about the preparations for the party. M: Right. I think we really need to plan better and get things done in advance this time. Still remember what a mess it was at the last party?
target: What do we know about the last party from the conversation? (A) It was pretty good. (B) It was rather dull. (C) It was not well organized.

input: W: I tried to catch the bus but couldn't make it. So I'm late for class. M: Another excuse. Are you ready for what you'll say tomorrow?
target: What does the man imply about the woman? (A) She should try to catch an earlier bus. (B) She is absent from his class too often. (C) She is always making excuses for being late.

input: M: What is Mr. Peterson going to do with his old house on London Road? Rent it or sell it? W: I heard he is thinking of turning it into a restaurant, which isn't a bad idea, because it's still a solid building.
target: What will Mr. Peterson do with his old house? (A) He may convert it and use it as a restaurant. (B) He may pull it down and build a new restaurant. (C) He may rent it out for use as a restaurant.

input: M: There is an exhibition about planes and satellites. W: Really? I'd like to see that, too.
target: What have they decided to do? (A) Visit. (B) Play. (C) Fly.

input: F: I go to work by bike every day, what about you, Peter? M: I go to work by bus, and seldom by bike.
target: How does Peter go to work every day? (A) By bike. (B) By bus. (C) On foot.

input: M: Jenny,you look pale today. Are you ill? W: I'm fine, I haven't been sleeping very well recently. The workers have been repairing the road near my house for the past two weeks.
target: Why does the woman look pale? (A) She is ill. (B) She is repairing a road. (C) She hasn't slept well.

input: W: I'm not going to trust the restaurant critic from that magazine again. The food here doesn't taste anything like what we had in Chinatown. M: It definitely wasn't worth the wait.
target: What do we learn from the conversation? (A) The restaurant was not up to the speakers' expectations. (B) The restaurant places many ads in popular magazines. (C) The critic thought highly of the Chinese restaurant.

input: M: Today is January 14, isn't it? W: That's right. Only nine days before Bob's birthday.
target: When is Bob's birthday? (A) January 14. (B) January 5. (C) January 23.

input: M: Where on earth are we? W: Judging by all the traffic, I'd say we're near the heart of the downtown area. M: What did I do wrong? Did I take a wrong turn? W: I think so.
target: What happened to the speakers? (A) They lost their way. (B) They were caught in the traffic. (C) They broke the traffic rule.

input: M: What can we do that's free and fun? W: Let's go to the history museum. Every first Sunday of the month, admission is free. That's tomorrow! Let's go.
target: What day is it today? (A) Monday. (B) Saturday. (C) Sunday.

input: W: Are those pictures in color or black and white? M: Some are black and white and others are in color.
target: What do we know about the pictures? (A) They are all in color (B) Not all of them are in color (C) They are all black and white

input: W: You look tired. M: Yeah, I am worn out. I've been surfing the Internet. W: Were you doing school work or playing games? M: Well, I wanted to get some information about Canada for my project, but I found a really interesting chat room with people from that country and started chatting. W: Did you get the information you needed? M: Yes, but then we spent a lot of time chatting about other interests.
target: What makes the man so tired? (A) Playing games. (B) Surfing the Internet. (C) Searching for interesting people.

input: F: Where did you go last month? M: We went to New York to visit my mother.
target: Where did the man go? (A) To China (B) To U.S.A (C) To Canada

input: M: Finished, Miss? W: Yes, can I have the bill, please?
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She wants the man to buy it. (B) She wants to buy it. (C) She doesn't want to buy it.

input: M: Are you staying long? W: No, unfortunately only a couple of weeks. M: On business or on holiday? W: Business,I'm afraid. My company is setting up an office in London.
target: Why is the woman in London? (A) She is on holiday. (B) She is on a business trip. (C) She is working for a company there.

input: M: Are you doing anything on Monday? W: Nothing special. Why? What's on Monday? M: I thought I'd have a party. W: Nice. What time? M: Evening. Nine o'clock. That sort of time. W: What's the celebration? M: Well, it's my birthday on Saturday, but I'll be away the whole weekend. W: Friday's a nice day to have a party, isn't it? M: Well, I was going to have it on Friday, but Friday has rather good TV programs. W: I know what you mean.
target: Why does the man talk to the woman? (A) To ask her for help. (B) To give her an invitation. (C) To ask her to bring something.

input: M: It's a beautiful day, isn't it? W: Yes, nice and sunny. M: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then. W: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best. M: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue. W: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend. M: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will. W: I don't think he's right. It hasn't rained for a week. M: But he is usually right in his weather news. W: I'm sure we'll have fine weather for our picnic.
target: What was the weather like last week? (A) Nice and sunny. (B) Too warm. (C) Neither hot nor cold.

input: M: I feel very ill, Doctor. W: What is the matter with you? M: I have a terrible sore throat. I have a headache, too. W: Have you been coughing and sneezing? M: I cough a lot, but I don't sneeze. W: Put this thermometer under your tongue. I want to see if you have a fever. Let me see. Yes. You have a fever. M: Is my temperature very high? W: No, not very. Here is a prescription. Stay in bed and rest. Drink hot tea. Come in and see me in my office on Monday.
target: What should the man drink a lot? (A) Coffee. (B) Hot tea. (C) Pure water.

input: W: So what do you think you are going to do when you graduate, John? M: I'm not sure. My dad says I should work in information technology. You know something with computers. W: Is that what your dad does? M: Not really. He is an engineer. W: How about you? What are you interested in doing? M: Well. I'm interested in medicine. I'd love to be a doctor. W: Yeah, what subject are you good at? M: Math is my best subject. And I'm also pretty good at science.
target: What might be the relationship between the two speakers? (A) Workmates. (B) Friends. (C) Mother and son.

input: M: Do you think home video players will replace movie theatres and force them out of the entertainment business? W: We're certainly faced with the grave challenge from the DVD industry. That's why I think we have to revolutionize our concept of movie showing. As I see it, the movie theatre should not just be a place to watch a film, but a place to meet people.
target: What does the woman think of the movie theatre? (A) It is a very good place to relax. (B) It should revolutionize its technology. (C) It should change its concept of operation.

input: W: What can I do for you, sir? M: I'm looking for a jacket for my son. W: Come with me, please. Here are the jackets for boys. M: The black one looks nice. How much is it? W: Twenty-five dollars. M: Oh, I am afraid it's too expensive. W: What about the blue one over there? It looks nice, too. And it's a little cheaper. M: But it's a bit too small. Have you got a bigger size? W: Sorry, we haven't. But we'll get some soon. Will you come back next week? M: All right. I'll come back then. Thanks.
target: What is the man going to do? (A) He is looking for the lost jacket of his son. (B) He wants to buy a jacket for himself. (C) He wants to buy a jacket for his son.

input: M: Though we didn't win the game, we were satisfied with our performance. W: You did a great job. You almost beat the world's champions. It's a real surprise to many people.
target: What do we learn from this conversation? (A) They both enjoyed watching the game. (B) The man thought the results were beyond their expectations. (C) They both felt good about the results of the game.

input: W: John, are you doing research for Professor Williams this semester? M: Actually, I am working as his teaching assistant.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He needs another job as research assistant. (B) He asked Professor Williams for assistance. (C) He assists Professor Williams with his teaching.

input: M: It's most possible that Jack will lose his job next month. F: Oh... yes... I've heard that too.
target: When will Jack lose his job? (A) Now. (B) Next month. (C) Next week.

input: W: Tell me about your English class. M: I can't stand it. The teacher is terrible.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He dislikes the English class.' (B) His English teacher is very kind. (C) The classroom is terrible.

input: M: You live in Washington, don't you? W: No. I work in Washington, but I live in Maryland. My home is in Potomac, Maryland. M: How far is it form Washington? W: It's not very far. Just about fifteen miles. M: So you commute from home to work. How do you like commuting? W: It's not bad. I'm used to it now. M: How long does it take? W: It depends on the traffic. It takes forty-five minutes in the morning, because the traffic is very bad then. M: I suppose the traffic is bad at the end of the day, too, when commuters are leaving the city. W: Yes. The worst time is between five and six. It sometimes takes me fifty minutes to drive home, if I can't leave Washington before five o'clock. M: How long does it take when there's not much traffic? W: Only twenty-five minutes. Commuting is easy then.
target: Where is the woman living now? (A) Washington. (B) Maryland. (C) Washington D.C.

input: M: Did you do anything last weekend? W: Not much. What did you do? M: I had planned to go skiing or do some shopping, but wound up studying.
target: What did the man do last weekend? (A) He went skiing. (B) He studied. (C) He did nothing.

input: M: I'm trying to make a call to New York and haven't been able to get through. Can you help me? W: Sure. Try my phone.
target: What is the man's problem? (A) He cannot hear the woman's call. (B) He cannot get through to New York. (C) He cannot recall the phone number.

input: M: Are you going to join the school swimming team this term? W: Swimming takes up too much of my time.
target: What can we learn about the woman from the dialogue? (A) She likes swimming very much. (B) She won't join the swimming team. (C) She doesn't enjoy swimming as much as she used to.

input: W: What's wrong? M: I left my keys inside. We're locked out. W: Doesn't the manager have an extra set? M: Sure, but I don't know if he's at home.
target: What's wrong with the man? (A) He forgot his appointment with his manager. (B) He left his keys at home. (C) He is locked out of his office.

input: M: Bob is running for chairman of the student union. Would you vote for him? W: Oh, I can't decide right now because I have to find out more about the other candidates.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) Bob does not have much chance to win. (B) She will vote for another candidate. (C) Bob cannot count on her vote.

input: F: Could you pass me the pen? I'd like to write down the phone number. M: Sure, here you are.
target: What does the woman want to write down? (A) She wants to write down her name. (B) She wants to write down the man's name. (C) She wants to write down a telephone number.

input: W: Did you see what that guy did? M: No. I was looking the other way. W: He made a U turn right in the middle of the block and almost hit a kid on a bicycle. M: Drivers get crazier every day!
target: What was the guy doing? (A) Driving a car. (B) Riding a bike. (C) Getting crazy.

input: M: Do we have to get the opera tickets in advance? W: Certainly. Tickets at the door are usually sold at a higher price.
target: What does the woman imply? (A) It's better to buy the tickets beforehand. (B) The tickets are sold in advance at half price. (C) It's difficult to buy the tickets on the spot.

input: M: Would you like to see those pants in brown and navy blue? These two colors are coming in this season. W: Oh, actually grey is my favorite color, but I prefer something made from cotton, 100% cotton I mean.
target: What is the woman looking for? (A) Grey pants made from pure cotton. (B) Fashionable pants in bright colors. (C) 100% cotton pants in dark blue.

input: W: I can't believe we got tickets to the baseball game! M: I know. I've wanted to see the team play all year. W: It's too bad that we are in the last row. M: That's okay. I just love the game. Do you think the game will start on time? W: I don't know. M: It has been raining hard. It would be a shame if we wasted our Sunday. W: It's not a waste. We are together! M: Yes, that is a wonderful point. W: And, even if they don't play baseball, it's nice to be outside. M: Yes, I do enjoy the rain.
target: What do they intend to watch? (A) A baseball game. (B) A basketball game. (C) A badminton game.

input: M: What do you think of these cookies? My wife made them. W: Very tasty indeed. Even my sister can't make such nice cookies.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The cookies taste delicious. (B) Her sister can make better cookies. (C) The cookies are made for her sister.

input: W: I need to find a dentist; you said you know Dr. Smith well, do you recommend her? M: Well, I had to see her a few times, but what impressed me most were the magazines in her waiting room.
target: What does the woman imply? (A) Dr. Smith's waiting room isn't tidy. (B) Dr. Smith may not be a good choice. (C) Dr. Smith has left a good impression on her.

input: W: Your dog certainly seems to know you are his master. Did you have to punish him very often when you trained him? M: I found it's much better to praise him when he obeys and not to be so fussy when he makes mistakes.
target: What does the man say about training dogs? (A) He has learned a lot from his own mistakes. (B) He is quite experienced in taming wild dogs. (C) He finds reward more effective than punishment.

input: W: We are going to visit the flower exhibition tomorrow. M: Are you? May I join you?
target: What does the man mean? (A) He is not interested in going. (B) He wants to go with them. (C) He will invite his friends.

input: M: Did you know this: after almost ten years in the United States, with such a strong accent. W: Yes, but he is proud of it. He says it is a part of his identity.
target: What does the conversation tell us about Mr. Li? Li still speaks English. (A) His English is still poor after ten years in America. (B) He doesn't mind speaking English with an accent. (C) He doesn't like the way Americans speak.

input: W: Hello, emergency line. What can I do for you? M: I am calling to report an accident. W: Could you give me some details, sir? M: A truck hit a car on Highway 204. W: Has anyone been badly hurt? M: I'm not quite sure. The driver of the truck says he is OK. But the lady in the car might have broken her leg. W: May I have your name, sir? M: Daniel Smith. W: OK, Mr. Smith. We'll send an ambulance and a police car immediately. It's 11:55 now, and they should be there by 12:05. Thanks.
target: Who is the man? (A) A passerby. (B) The car driver. (C) The truck driver.

input: W: Some people are always after large, short-term profits. And they become victims of financial tricks. M: Well, they should know that if something seems too good to be true, it probably is.
target: What does the man think people should know? (A) Risks may exist when they chase high profits in a short time. (B) It's feasible for people to be after large short-term profits. (C) No one can avoid being victims of financial tricks.

input: W: Don't throw paper on the floor, Mike. M: Where shall I put it, Miss? W: Put it in the waste-paper basket, please. M: But Tom and Bill put all their paper in the basket a few minutes ago. Now it's full. W: Then take the basket outside and empty it. M: Yes, Miss. W: Where did you empty the basket, Mike? M: On the playground, Miss. W: That's not right! The dustbin is at the back of the school. Now pick up the paper and put it in the dustbin.
target: Why did the man put the paper on the floor? (A) He saw other people do so. (B) The basket was thrown away. (C) The basket was full.

input: W: ABC company. Can I help you? M: Can you put me through to Mr Brown in the Sales Department? W: I'm afraid Mr Brown is at a meeting at the moment. M: Can I leave a message? W: Certainly. M: Can you ask Mr Brown to call me at 1300-621-7865? W: Who is calling, please? M: Alan Peterson. W: OK. Mr Peterson. Can you repeat the phone number? M: That's 1300-621-7865. W: OK. I'll ask Mr Brown to call you as soon as the meeting is over. M: Thanks. Bye.
target: Where is Mr Brown? (A) He is in the Sales Department. (B) He is having a meeting. (C) He is busy.

input: W: The Painting Club. Can I help you? M: Yes. I'd like to ask about the painting classes. W: OK. We have some classes starting the week of February 20th lasting seven weeks and meeting twice a week. M: How much does it cost? W: $140. That's $10 for each lesson. M: How much does it cost if I am a member of the Painting Club? W: It's half price. Members pay half. M: I see. W: And classes start in February. You can come to put down your name on February 16th or 17th if you have decided to attend the classes. M: Thanks. W: You are welcome.
target: On which day of February will the painting class start? (A) 16th. (B) 18th. (C) 20th.

input: W: Harold, could you slow down a little bit? M: We're late, Jane. And I'm worried that we might run into traffic around Broadway, so I'm just trying to get there as fast as possible... Oh my God! Did you see what that bus just did? W: I knew we should have taken the subway.
target: Where are the two speakers probably? (A) In a car. (B) On the subway. (C) On a bus.

input: M: Did you sing or play a musical instrument? The piano, for example. W: Well, I did learn to play the piano as a child. But I gave it up. I'm afraid I can't sing either. But I am good at playing the violin.
target: Which of the following is true about the woman? (A) She sings very well. (B) She's a popular musician. (C) She is interested in music.

input: M: Chinese ink painting is an important part of your nation al culture, isn't it, Miss Li? W: Yes, it has a history of over 2 500 years.
target: When can the history of Chinese ink painting be traced back? (A) 1 500 years ago. (B) 2 000 years ago. (C) 2 500 years ago.

input: M: Janet, do you know anything about this author's latest best seller? W: Sure. I've just read through it. I strongly recommend it. I have a copy at home. If you want to read the book, I will bring it tomorrow. M: Oh, you're so kind. Thank you very much.
target: What are the man and woman talking about? (A) A book. (B) Music. (C) A film.

input: M: Terry starts work at six o'clock. W: So he has to get up early.
target: Why does Terry get up early? (A) Because he has to go outside. (B) Because he has to work early. (C) Because he has to catch the bus.

input: M: Mary, would you like to go to the movies with me after dinner? W: Well, I'll go if you really want me to, but I'm rather tired.
target: What can we conclude from this conversation? (A) The woman does not want to go to the movies. (B) The man is too tired to go to the movies. (C) The woman wants to go to the movies.

input: M: I am going to New York next week, but the hotel I booked is really expensive. W: Why book a hotel? My brother has 2 spare rooms in his apartment.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The man can stay in her brother's apartment. (B) Her brother can help the man find a cheaper hotel. (C) Her brother can find an apartment for the man.

input: W: Hello, Old Tree Cafe. Can I help you? M: Yes, I'd like to book a table for ten of us tonight. W: Ten? We don't usually accept large parties, sir. M: I know, but we are regular customers. Can you figure out a solution for me? W: Emm. All right! We'll put two tables together.
target: Why doesn't the Care usually accept large parties? (A) Small tables. (B) Poor service (C) Lack of waitresses.

input: W: Hi, are you Don? I'm Lynn. I saw the advertisement you put on the Internet about selling your car. M: Hi, Lynn. Nice to meet you. Thanks for your interest. Here's my car. It's a 2006 Honda Civic. I took a lot of road trips in it! It is not perfect, but it is safe to drive and it has new tires. W: Is anything broken? M: The radio is broken and the heater is broken, but the air conditioner works well. W: I think you should lower the price because the radio and the heater are broken. If you don't lower the price, I don't think I want to buy it. M: Sorry, but I'm not lowering the price. It's a very safe car, even if the radio is broken. Would you like to drive the car so you can see if you like it? W: No, thank you. I am worried something else is broken too.
target: Where did Lynn learn about the car? (A) In the newspaper. (B) On a road trip. (C) On the Internet.

input: M: I like sports, all kinds of sports. W: One ought to be quite strong to be active in sports, don't you think? M: Yeah, and being active in sports helps a lot to keep up one's health. Why don't you take up something, such as tennis, jogging or swimming as a hobby? W: I want to do something different, that is, something relaxing and enjoyable. Can you suggest a hobby other than active sports? M: Mmm, yes. I can suggest a hobby. Photography is enjoyable and relaxing. What do you think of it? W: It certainly is a good hobby. But, it costs a lot, doesn't it?
target: What are the two speakers talking about? (A) School. (B) The weather. (C) Hobbies.

input: M: How much are these cups, please? W: Four yuan for each or seven for two.
target: How much does one cup cost if you buy two? (A) 8 yuan. (B) 4 yuan. (C) 3.5 yuan.

input: W: I'm feeling bored with being sick in bed. What if I didn't have those magazines to read? M: Well, if it helps, I'll run to the store to get you some new ones. W: Thanks a lot, Bill.
target: What will the man probably do? (A) Buy the woman some magazines. (B) Help the woman find a new doctor. (C) Read the woman some magazine articles.

input: M: Excuse me, where do you live? W: I live at No. 145, Shanghai Road.
target: What's the woman's address? (A) No. 105, DongFang Road.' (B) No. 45, Taibei Road. (C) No. 145, Shanghai Road.

input: F: Is this your book, Steven? M: No, it isn't mine. It's Sam's.
target: Whose book is this? (A) Sam's. (B) Steven's. (C) We don't know.

input: M: Hi, Jenny, how are you getting on with your packing? W: I am still deciding what to take with me.
target: What can we learn about Jenny? (A) She needs more time for packing. (B) She never hesitates over what to take. (C) She hates packing by herself.

input: M: Julie, John asked me to talk to you? W: I don't want to speak to him. M: Look, Julie, John's really sorry about it. W: I'm sorry about it, too. M: Will you just let me tell you his side of the story? W: I'm not interested. He promised to meet me at the restaurant, but he didn't come. I don't want to see him again. M: But, Julie, his car had broken down. W: So? There is a telephone in the restaurant. M: But that's the point. He tried to phone, but he couldn't get through. W: I don't believe he tried. M: Yes, he did. He came to my flat. Do you believe me? W: Yes, I'll talk to him. Listen, I'm going to be late for work, I'll meet him at five to six in the square. M: Thanks, Julie. He'll be really happy. And I promise he'll be here.

input: M: I ran into our friend Mark yesterday on the street, and he said he hadn't heard from you for two months. W: Yes, I know, but I've been too busy to phone him.

input: W: I wonder what's happened to Jerry. He hasn't been around for at least 2 weeks. M: He took a leave to see his mother in Europe.
