M: We went on a picnic on Sunday. W: Did you like it? M: Very enjoyable. By the way, Lisa. what about your Weekend? W: Don't ask me. Mike. M: What happened? W: I have got a cold. I could do nothing but lie in bed. M: Oh. dear.
target: What did Mike do last week? (A) He went to visit his grandma in the countryside. (B) He went for a picnic with his friend in the park. (C) He stayed at home and doing nothing.

input: M: I am surprised to see you using the record player I was going to throw away! W: It still works. You'd better get fid of these wasteful habits.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The record player is still useful. (B) The man shouldn't have thrown it away. (C) The man should abandon his bad habit.

input: W: Which cap did you finally decide to buy? M: Well, I would have liked to buy the blue one, but it was 20 dollars. So I bought another one instead and saved $5.
target: How much did the man pay? (A) $10. (B) $15. (C) $20.

input: W: Well, I find No. 258 rather attractive. M: You know, quality is as much important as the price.
target: What does the man imply? (A) The quality is more important than the price. (B) The quality is less important than the price. (C) The quality and the price are important.

input: M: Kate, I thought Lisa's birthday party was supposed to be at your place. W: It was, Jack, but my parents decided to come for a visit that week. M: So where will the party be? W: At Lily and Jade's place.
target: Who is the birthday party for? (A) Jade. (B) Lisa. (C) Lily.

input: W: Do you often call your parents? M: I'm too busy, so I only call them once a week.
target: How often does the man call his parents? (A) Every day. (B) Never. (C) Once a week.

input: W: Isn't Frank supposed to arrive in Chicago this morning? Ms. Tylor is waiting for him. M: He's just called to say his flight was canceled. He won't be able to arrive until the afternoon. W: Hmm, could you call him and ask him to email his report to Ms. Tylor then?
target: What do you know about Frank? (A) He will arrive in Chicago this morning. (B) He will send Ms. Tyler an e-mail. (C) He will call Ms. Tyler himself.

input: W: What are we going to get for Lydia's birthday? M: How about a pair of running shoes? W: You know she hates doing exercise. M: Then I guess we can buy her a birthday cake.
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) Having a birthday party. (B) Doing some exercise. (C) Getting Lydia a gift.

input: W: A ticket for an adult is 10 dollars and for a child half price. M: I want one ticket for adult and two tickets for children.
target: How much will the man pay for these tickets? (A) 15 dollars. (B) 20 dollars. (C) 25 dollars.

input: M: Well, the holiday is well soon be here. W: Yes, isn't it exciting by this time next week, we'll be on the plane?
target: What do we learn from the conversation? (A) The woman doesn't think it exciting to travel by air. (B) They'll be flying somewhere for their vacation. (C) They are offered some plane ticketsfor their holidays.

input: M: Miss Smith, I told Dr. Brown that I would call him in the Houston office at ten o'clock by their time. Please find out the time difference for me so that I'll know when to place the call. W: It's two hours earlier in Houston, sir. I know without looking it up because my sister lives there.
target: When should the man place his call to Houston? (A) At 8:00. (B) At 10:00. (C) At 12:00.

input: W: Sir,there's a Mr Miller on the phone who wants to talk to you. M: I'm busy at the moment. Can you ask him to hold on?Tell him I'll talk with him in a few seconds.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He is waiting for someone else. (B) He doesn't want to talk with Mr Miller. (C) He is busy now.

input: W: Very nice skirts. How much axe they? M: Ten dollars each. And one dollar off if you may buy two.
target: How much will the woman pay if she buys two skirts? (A) $ 9. (B) $ 19. (C) $ 20.

input: W: If I were you,I'd take the bus to work. Driving in that rush hour traffic is terrible. M: But by the time the bus gets to my stop, there aren't any seats left.
target: How does the man prefer to go to work? (A) By train. (B) By car. (C) By bus.

input: W: What are you going to do this afternoon? M: I told Frank I'd help him work on his car.
target: What did the man plant to do? (A) To help Frank repair his car. (B) To drive Frank's car. (C) To help Frank sell his car.

input: W: Why weren't you at the German class last night, Tom? Have you given up? M: Well, no...I came back late yesterday and found John sleeping in the chair. He'd been writing a report all day long and he was too tired to go out again, so we gave the lesson a miss. W: You've missed quite a lot of lessons lately, haven't you? Are you losing interest? M: Yes, I'm afraid so. Neither John nor I have a gift for language. People just laugh at us when we attempt to speak German. How did you and Jane pick it up so quickly and easily? You've hardly been in Germany a month. W: It was neither quick nor easy. We'd both studied the language before we came, and we only needed to revise it. M: Anyway, all our friends here speak English very well, so we don't really need to learn German.
target: What's the relationship between the woman and the man? (A) Teacher and student. (B) Mother and son. (C) Classmates.

input: M: What are you doing? W: I'm parking my car here. M: No, I'm sorry. It's impossible. W: Why not? I don't see a "No Parking" sign. M: This is my parking place. W: I don't see a sign with your name. M: I park here every day. W: Well, I'm parking here today.
target: What are they quarrelling about? (A) Going to a park. (B) Parking their cars. (C) A parking sign.

input: W: I don't imagine you have any interest in attending my lecture on drawing, do you? M: Oh, yes, I do. Not that you remind me of it.
target: What do we learn about the man from the conversation? (A) He's going to attend the lecture. (B) He doesn't mind if the woman goes to the lecture. (C) He'd rather not go to the lecture.

input: W: Why don't you go into the room? M: Oh, my key won't turn in the lock. Will you help me?
target: Why doesn't the woman go into the room? (A) She can't unlock the door. (B) She has lost the key. (C) She wants to wait till the man comes.

input: M: You look quite different from what you used to. W: Sure. I started exercising regularly two years ago and went from 253 pounds to a healthy 160 pounds and that is the only thing I did not give up halfway.
target: What do we know about woman? (A) She lost a lot of weight in two years. (B) She had a unique way of staying healthy. (C) She stopped exercising two years ago.

input: M: Excuse me, could you please tell me the way to the city library? W: I'm sorry. I'm a stranger here myself, but if you cross the road and ask in the police station which is beside the supermarket, I'm sure they'll help you.
target: Where is the man going? (A) The police station. (B) The city library. (C) The supermarket.

input: M: Good morning. May I help you? W: I'd like to exchange some money first. M: Anything else? W: Then open a saving account.
target: Where does the conversation most probably take place? (A) In a post office. (B) In a hotel. (C) In a bank.

input: M: Hi, Linda. Could you help me do some office work? I've fired my secretary. W: OK. But why did you fire her? M: She always can't finish typing the letters in time.
target: What kind of secretary does the man need? (A) One typing very fast. (B) One going to work on time. (C) One helping him with letters.

input: M: My roommate and I are going to see a film tonight. And we are leaving at 7:40. Do you want to join us? W: Sure. But my class ends at 7:30. And the professor never finishes on time.
target: What can we learn about the woman? (A) She is not sure if she can join them. (B) She will skip the class to see the film. (C) She will ask the professor for leave.

input: M: Hello, may I speak to Peter? W: Sorry, he's out. May I take a message for him?
target: Where are the two speakers talking? (A) On a bus. (B) In the office over the telephone. (C) On the train.

input: M: Well, let's make our appointment around two o'clock this afternoon. W: Fine. I'll come to your office either at two o'clock or earlier if I can. M: All right. The sooner the better.
target: What time does the man expect the woman to come? (A) At sharp 2:00 p.m. (B) Before 2:00 p.m. (C) Any time in the afternoon.

input: W: If you can help me with this job, I would finish it before 5 o'clock M: I would like to, but Mr. Golden told me to type some letters before I went home.
target: What did Mr. Golden ask the man to do? (A) Go home at 5 o'clock. (B) Work together with Mr. Golden. (C) Type some letters.

input: M: Have you seen the ski shop that's just opened in the High Street? W: Yes, it opened last week, didn't it? I haven't been there yet.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She hasn't been inside the new ski shop. (B) She has been to the Ski shop. (C) She doesn't know about this shop.

input: W: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock. M: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring? W: Yes, it did. M: But I didn't hear it at all. W: What time did you set it for last night? M: Six o'clock. W: Hurry up, or you'll be late for school. Are you feeling ill? M: No. I'm only sleepy because I stayed awake the whole night. W: Breakfast is ready. Get dressed and get out of bed. Don't forget to wash you face and brush your teeth before you eat breakfast. M: OK, I'm coming.
target: When had Tom planned to get up this morning? (A) At 6:00. (B) At 6:30. (C) At 7:00.

input: M: Should I turn left here? F: No, keep going straight and turn at the next light.
target: What should the man do? (A) Turn left (B) Go straight (C) Turn right

input: M: Hello, Mary. Is it true that you're going to leave us? W: Maybe, but it still depends on Jack. If he gets that job, then we'll have to move to Boswell. M: You're going to miss Highland Park, aren't you? W: Oh, definitely. But it's a much greater opportunity for Jack. His salary will be much higher. Also, there are better schools for the children. The town itself isn't half as nice as Highland Park, though. M: Are you going to stop working? W: I may get a job as a teacher. There's a new highschool in Boswell, and they're looking for teachers.
target: What kind of job will Jack have? (A) A job as a salesman. (B) Teaching. (C) A job with more money.

input: W: Hello, glad to see you. Come in, please. M: Thanks. It looks like the party is exciting and all are in high spirits. W: My brother, Tom is visiting me for the weekend. M: Where is he? W: He is sitting in the corner over there, and beside the yound woman. M: And who is the yound woman? Uh, the woman wearing a red coat. W: Oh, that's Ann, my piano teacher. M: Piano teacher! I never knew you were practicing the piano.
target: Who is visiting the woman for the weekend? (A) Her brother. (B) Her student. (C) Her teacher.

input: W: I'm not sure about this soup, Carl. It has no taste. M: No! I don't think so, Maria. It tastes fine to me. We've been to this place before, and I don't feel the soup tastes any different. W: Well, I still think it needs something. Salt? M: No, certainly not. What about pepper? If anything, I think it could use a little more of that. W: Now you're talking. That's exactly what it needs. And how about some more onions too? M: I don't know about that. You seem to be starting to like food with strong tastes recently. W: Oh, really?
target: What does Maria think of the soup? (A) Tasteless. (B) Just fine. (C) Thick.

input: M: Do you always look over your own papers for typing mistakes? W: I usually have to do it myself, but I'd rather have someone else proofread them.
target: What would the woman prefer to do? (A) To check the typing mistakes by herself. (B) To ask someone else to check her papers. (C) To type her papers by herself.

input: W: Does the play start at 6:00 or 6:15? M: Neither. It starts at 6:30 and ends at 8:00.
target: When does the play start? (A) At 6:30. (B) At 8:00. (C) At 6:00.

input: W: If you're going to the airport, what about our dinner? M: I'll meet you for dinner after I've been to the airport.
target: What are they going to do together? (A) To go to the airport (B) To go to a meeting (C) To have dinner

input: M: I'm getting worried about Jenny's school work. All she talks about these days is volleyball games and all she does is practice, training and things like that. W: Her grades on the coming exams will fall for sure. It's high time we talk(ed) some sense to her.
target: What are the speakers probably going to do? (A) Urge Jenny to spend more time on study. (B) Help Jenny to prepare for the coming exams. (C) Act towards Jenny in a more sensible way.

input: W: Did you find the book for your reading assignment in the library? M: It closed before I got there. I had no idea that it closes so early on weekends.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He didn't get the book he needed. (B) He had no idea where the book was. (C) The library is closed on weekends.

input: W: How can I get to the airport? M: You can to there by subway, by bus, or by taxi. The subway is the quickest, but the bus is the cheapest.
target: What can we learn from the conversation? (A) It saves time to go by subway. (B) It saves money to go by subway. (C) There's no direct bus to the airport.

input: W: What are your plans for the future? M: My dream is to open my own business after I graduate.
target: What is the man probably doing now? (A) He is working for a business company. (B) He is doing his own business. (C) He is studying at a university.

input: M: Are all the children grown up now, Ruth? W: Oh, yes. Laura is the most clever one. She's a librarian in the public library. M: Very interesting. And what about Rita? W: She's a secretary at the railway station. M: And what about Rosemary? She was always a very pretty child. W: Rosemary is a waitress in a restaurant in Paris. She's married to an engineer. M: How about the boys, Jerry and Roland? W: Jerry drives a bus. He drives everywhere in Europe. M: Really? In which countries does he drive? W: France, Austria, Greece and Russia. M: And does Roland drive a bus, too? W: Oh, no. Roland is a pilot. M: Good. Where does he fly? W: To Australia and America.

input: W: Could you tell me what I should do if my car breaks down? M: Well, I'm sure you won't have any trouble, Mrs. Smith, but if something should happen, just call this number. They'll see that you get help.
target: What does the man really mean? (A) He meant she should make a phone call if anything went wrong. (B) He meant for her just to wait till help came. (C) He was afraid something would go wrong with her car.

input: W: Look! They are lining up at Gate 10. M: Hurry up. It's time to check in for our train.
target: Where does the dialogue take place? (A) In a railway station. (B) In an airport. (C) In a theatre.

input: W: David, what do you like to do in your spare time? M: I like to play sports. W: Which sport do you play the most -- volleyball, basketball, baseball, or football? M: The last one. When I was in high school, I was a forward. W: You're more active than I am. I like reading, photography, and computers. M: I don't know much about computers. I don't have a computer. W: Really? But you can't get on the Internet without that! M: That's right. I use the library's computers when I read my e-mail. W: Well, I know what you need for your birthday!
target: Which sport does the man play the most often? (A) Football. (B) Baseball. (C) Basketball.

input: M: Excuse me. Are you Linda's sister? W: No, I'm her cousin.
target: Who is the woman? (A) Linda's mother. (B) Linda's cousin. (C) Linda's aunt.

input: M: Hello! I haven't seen you before. W: I'm new here. I have just arrived at this school. M: Really? Let me take you to your class. Which class are you in? W: I don't know. M: Never mind. I will show you to the teachers' office. Come with me. W: Thanks! Oh, by the way, I don't know where to put this bike. M: Oh, you have got a bike, haven't you? You can put it over there. W: It is very kind of you. Thank you. M: Not at all. This way, please.
target: Where does the conversation take place? (A) In a school. (B) In a shop. (C) In a teacher's office.

input: W: Hello, Ben. You're getting ready for tomorrow's lessons, aren't you? M: Yes, but I'm a bit nervous. I have no idea what'll happen in class and how I'll get along with my classmates. W: I understand how you're feeling. Just take it easy. You'll make a lot of friends very soon. M: Thank you. I'll try my best to get used to my new school life as soon as possible. By the way, what time does the first class begin? W: At 8 o'clock. But before that we have 10 minutes to hand in homework and then 20 minutes for morning reading. M: So we must get to school before 7:30, right? W: Right. M: How long does each class last? W: 45 minutes, I think, with a 10 or 15 minutes' break. M: Well, I hear that lunchtime is nearly 12 o'clock and I'll be starving by then. W: Don't worry. During the break after the second class, we can buy something to eat. M: That's good.
target: What should the students do before morning reading? (A) Do morning exercise. (B) Hand in homework. (C) Do their homework.

input: M: Prof. Jackson, we were wondering if we could sit in your English class? W: I wish I could say "yes". But if I accepted you two, I wonder how to say "No" to a lot of others who have raised the same request.
target: What does the professor mean? (A) She accepted their request. (B) She rejected their request. (C) She agreed to consider their request.

input: W: I have a sore throat and a runny nose. M: Here is your medicine. Take these once in the morning and once before you go to bed at night.
target: How often should the woman take the medicine? (A) Once a day. (B) Twice a day. (C) Three times a day.

input: M: Good morning. How can I help you? W: I'd like to buy a student bus pass. M: We have weekly, monthly and yearly ones. Which do you want? W: Monthly, please.
target: What kind of student bus pass does the woman want? (A) Weekly. (B) Monthly. (C) Yearly.

input: M: Can you come to my office at 9 tomorrow morning? W: I'm afraid not. I'll send the form to the headquarters then.
target: Why can't the woman go to the man's office? (A) She will meet the manager. (B) She will go to the headquarters. (C) She will fill in the forms.

input: W: Can I help you, sir? M: Yes, please. I'd like to have a pair of shoes. W: What size would you like, please? M: Size eleven. W: OK. What about this pair? M: Sorry, I don't like white. Have you got any other colors? W: Oh, yes. We have also got blue, brown and black. M: Can I have a look at the black ones? Black is my favourite colour. W: Sure. Here you are. M: They look nice. What's the price? W: Fifty dollars. M: May I try them on? W: Yes, please. M: OK. I'll take this pair. Here's the money. W: Thank you.
target: What does the man want to buy? (A) Trousers. (B) Socks. (C) Shoes.

input: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry! B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong? A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go. B: How come? A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it. B: We can go next week instead. A: No, I don't want to ruin your weekend. You go ahead and please take the book I bought to my friend Sally. Tell her I have to study all weekend, because I can't afford to fail the test. B: Ok, then I'll go with Dan. But it's a pity you can't come.
target: Why does Diana say sorry to peter? (A) She has to give up her travel pan. (B) She wants to visit another city. (C) She needs to put off her test.

input: W: So, are you leaving for the US tonight? M: Don't ask. I'm now killing. W: Why? M: Because I have to stay here for a meeting with my boss. W: Oh, well, never mind, now you can come to Joy's party tonight.
target: How is the man feeling? (A) Disappointed (B) Encouraged (C) Delighted

input: W: I'd like to reserve a table for dinner. Do you have one by the window? M: Certainly. How many people are in your party?
target: What is the probable relationship between the speakers? (A) Friends. (B) Doctor and patient. (C) Customer and waiter.

input: M: Happy birthday! I bought you the new Taylor Swift CD. W: Thanks! But I already have her CD. I will give it to my sister. She will be so excited.
target: Why doesn't the woman want the CD? (A) She already owns one. (B) She doesn't like the singer. (C) Her sister likes the singer more.

input: W: Hello, Dan. I was sorry to hear that you had an accident last week. How did it happen and how are you feeling now? M: Well, I was riding on my bicycle along the street when a taxi driver suddenly made a sharp turn in front of me. I could not stop my bicycle in time and I was knocked down. Fortunately, I only got a broken arm and a broken leg. The doctor said that I would have to stay in hospital for at least a week. W: Do your arm and leg hurt now? M: Yes, my leg hurts badly, but I can bear the pain. The only thing that I'm worried about is my classes. You know, next week we're going to have our mid-term exams. W: Well, don't worry about the exams. I can help you. M: Thank you, but I don't really want to stay here that long. Anyway, thank you for coming to see me.
target: What is the most probable relationship between the two speakers? (A) Classmates. (B) Doctor and patient. (C) Teacher and student.

input: M: It seems that we'll have another fine day tomorrow. Let's go to the seaside. W: OK. But we'll have to leave very early, or else we'll get caught in the traffic.
target: Why does the woman suggest going early? (A) Because they can back home early. (B) Because they'll get caught in the traffic. (C) Because they will have a good view.

input: W: Can you believe that we've finally found a house? M: Good for you. Tell me about the house! W: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside. M: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have? W: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen. M: Then your two boys don't need to share a room. They are happy with it? W: Yeah, they can have their own rooms. What interests me most is the small garden before the house. You know I love gardening so much.
target: What are the two speakers talking about? (A) Their new house. (B) The woman's new house. (C) The man's new house.

input: M: The guests are leaving for New York today on the ten o'clock flight. We need someone to get them to the airport on time. W: Ordinarily, I'd be happy to, but my car is in the garage.
target: How are the guests going to New York? (A) By bus. (B) By plane. (C) By car.

input: M: Susan, how are you? I heard you were sick? W: They must have confused me with somebody else. I've never felt better.
target: How does Susan feel? (A) She feels fine. (B) She feels sick. (C) She does feel well.

input: W: It was a heavy storm last night, wasn't it? M: It certainly was. The wind broke several windows. What weather! W: Do you know that big tree in front of my house? One of the biggest branches came down in the night. M: Really? Did it do any damage to your home? W: Thank goodness! It is far away from that. M: I really hate storms. It's about time we had some nice spring weather. W: It's April, you know. The flowers are beginning to blossom. M: Yes, that's true. But I still think the weather is terrible. W: I suppose we should not complain. We had a fine March after all.
target: What happened to the tree? (A) The tree was broken. (B) All the leaves fell down. (C) One of the branches fell down.

input: M: Hey, you should be doing your art class now. Why are you here? W: I realized I've no talent for drawing. Drama is a better alternative than those brushes.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She has dropped out of art and is now in drama. (B) She has run out of paintbrushes. (C) She doesn't feel like going to class.

input: W: How long did you have to write your paper? M: We were given 150 minutes, but I finished in less than half the time.
target: How long did it take the man to finish his paper? (A) Less than 75 minutes. (B) Less than 100 minutes. (C) Less than 150 minutes.

input: W: Five pounds for this cup of coffee? I think it's disgraceful, don't you? M: Oh, it's rather expensive.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The price for the coffee is fair. (B) The price is cheap. (C) The price is expensive.

input: M: I think I should give up playing tennis. I always lose. W: Just because you lost? Is that the reason to quit?
target: What does the woman rally mean? (A) The man should go on playing tennis. (B) She will give the man some tips on tennis. (C) The man has a good reason to quite tennis.

input: M: How do you like this oil painting? W: If I had enough room in my apartment, I would buy it.
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) A kind of oil (B) An apartment (C) A painting

input: M: Oh, it's you, Mrs. Bramley. Come in and sit down. Now, what was it? Oh, yes, your ankle. Has there been any improvement since last week? W: Well, no, I'm afraid not, doctor. The leg's still the same. M: I'd better have another look at it. HM! It's still very swollen. Have you been resting it, as! told you to? W: It's so difficult to rest it, doctor, you know, with a house to run, and six children to look after. M: Well, I've given you my advise. I'm sorry, but rest is necessary, otherwise I wouldn't have insisted on it. You must sit for at least four hours a day with the leg raised. Otherwise the ankle isn't going to improve. You understand that? W: Yes, I understand, and I'll try to do as you say. M: Very well then. I'll repeat that prescription for tablets, but the only effective treatment is rest. Ask the next patient to come in please.
target: What's wrong with the woman? (A) Her ankle is swollen. (B) Her uncle's health has not improved. (C) She can't understand the doctor.

input: M: The pictures we took at the botanical garden should be ready tomorrow. W: I can't wait to see them, I'm wondering if the shots I took are as good as I thought.
target: What is the woman eager to know? (A) How the pictures will turn out. (B) Where the botanical garden is. (C) What the man thinks of the shots.

input: W: I'm sorry you didn't win, Don. M: So am I. What a disappointment! W: Come on, cheer up! M: No, I feel terrible. And so do our classmates. W: But you tried your best, didn't you? M: Yes, I did. W: You won't give up trying, will you? M: No, I won't. I'll do better next time. W: I'll help you. We can practice together. M: That would be great. W: Then don't look so sad. M: I'll try to cheer up. W: You'll get over it. M: I know, thank you. W: Come on, I'll buy you a coffee. M: Oh, let's go.
target: How did the woman feel about the result of the game? (A) Cheerful. (B) Excited. (C) Disappointed.

input: W: Have you had a chance to wear your new shirt yet? M: That reminds me. I've been meaning to exchange it for a large size.
target: What does the man mean? (A) The man forgets to wear his new shirt. (B) The new shirt doesn't fit him. (C) He has no chance to wear his new shirt.

input: M: I haven't got my scores on the GRE test yet. Do you think I should call to make inquiries? W: There is no hurry. The test scores are released at least eight weeks after the test.
target: What does the woman advise the man to do? (A) Take the GRE test again in 8 weeks. (B) Call to check his scores. (C) Be patient and wait.

input: M: Is this the check-in counter for Flight 914 to Los Angeles? M: Yes, but I'm sorry the flight is delayed because of a minor mechanical problem. Please wait for further notice.
target: What do we learn from this conversation? (A) The man went to a wrong check-in counter. (B) The man has just missed his flight. (C) The plane's departure time remains unknown.

input: M: What happened to you? You're so late. W: My bike had some trouble, and I had to walk.
target: Why did the woman have to walk? (A) There was something wrong with her back. (B) Something happen ed to her bike. (C) She got up too late to catch the bus.

input: W: I'll wear this blue jacket. I like the color on me, don't you think? M: I think it looks terrific on you, really.
target: What does the man think of the woman's choice of clothing? (A) He thinks her choice is good. (B) He thinks her choice is terrible. (C) He doesn't like the colour.

input: W: I just need a little bit more information. Can you tell me your telephone number and mailing address? M: Sure. My number is 545-8897, and I live at 908 Millbury Street.
target: What is the man's telephone number? (A) 545-8897 (B) 908-8897 (C) 545-8908

input: W: I've never seen you have such confidence before an exam. M: It's more than confidence. Right now I feel that if I get less than an A, it'll be the fault of the exam itself.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He enjoys finding fault with exams. (B) He is sure of his success in the exam. (C) He doesn't know if he can do well in the exam.

input: F: Would you like to go swimming with me this afternoon? M: Yes. That's a good idea.
target: What will they do? (A) They will go swimming. (B) They will go for a walk. (C) They will go to a cinema.

input: F: Excuse me, can you show me which one is Mrs. Black? M: Sure. There, the one in red.
target: Which one is Mrs. Black? (A) The one with a red hat. (B) The one in green. (C) The one in red.

input: W: Happy New Year. M: The same to you.
target: What festival is it today? (A) New Year's Day. (B) Christmas. (C) Mid-autumn Day.

input: M: Have you been to the photo show, Mary? F: Yes, I have.
target: Where had Mary been? (A) Photo show. (B) Photo shop. (C) Market.

input: W: Hello, Li Ming. Have you heard from Tom recently? M: Yes. I got a letter from him yesterday.
target: Who wrote a letter to Li Ming? (A) Li Ming. (B) Tom. (C) A girl.

input: W: The play was wonderful. M: Do you really think so?
target: What does the man mean? (A) He doesn't like the play. (B) He agrees with the woman. (C) He has nothing to say about it.

input: M: Tell me what happened. W: Well, I wasn't paying attention when I started to cross the street, and I stepped in front of a taxi. I didn't realize it was still moving. M: Can you walk? W: Not very well. M: Where does it hurt? W: My side hurts when I take a step? M: Okay, don't try to walk anymore. Don't worry. An ambulance is on the way. You know, you're very lucky; you could have easily been killed in the accident. W: Yes, I guess I could have. M: You'll have to fill out a form. Do you have any identification with you? W: I have my passport. By the way, how did you get here so fast? M: Someone dialed 911 and reported the accident. We were in the area and got a radio call. It only took a minute or so to get here.
target: What happened to the woman? (A) She couldn't cross a busy street. (B) She got into a moving taxi. (C) She got hurt by a taxi.

input: M: I left 20 pages here to copy. Here is the receipt. W: I'm sorry, sir. But we're a little behind. Could you come back in a few minutes?
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She will give him the receipt later. (B) The man should make his own copies. (C) She has not got the man's copies ready.

input: M: You look tired. Why don't you go and have a good rest? W: I wish I could, but I have to finish my report. My boss will need it tomorrow.
target: Why is the woman still working? (A) Because she doesn't like to have a rest. (B) Because she wishes to be a boss someday. (C) Because she has to finish her report.

input: M: The doctor told me to stop drinking coffee. W: Shouldn't you stop drinking tea, too?
target: What does the woman suggest? (A) Tea is better than coffee. (B) The man shouldn't drink tea either. (C) The man should drink tea.

input: M: What's your favorite kind of music? W: I love jazz. I have over 50 jazz CDs. What about you? M: I love all kinds of music -- jazz, rock, classical, and folk.
target: What kind of music does the woman like? (A) Jazz. (B) Classical. (C) Folk.

input: M: Hello, Susan. Could I speak to Jim, please? F: I'm afraid he is not here now.
target: Whom did the man want to speak to? (A) Susan. (B) Jim. (C) Neither Susan nor Jim.

input: W: Are those my records? M: Oh, they are not. They are mine. W: Well, that's my radio. M: This isn't your radio. Yours is downstairs. W: Dad, Johnny has my radio. M: Oh, Brenda, there's another one downstairs. W: That one isn't good.
target: What's the relationship between the two speake rs? (A) They are classmates. (B) They are brother and sister. (C) They are roommates.

input: M: Can you stay for tea? W: I'd like to, but I have to pick up some groceries before the children get home from school.
target: Where is the woman going now? (A) To school. (B) Home. (C) To the grocery store.

input: M: Excuse me, the micle is in the right way for a few far? W: I'm afraid not. M: Oh, how can I get there? W: Are you on third? M: Unfortunately, yes. W: Well. It's easy enough to get there. You need to go down this road till you see a track on your left. Maybe half a mile off. M: Half a mile, ok. W: Then, take that track and keep going for another half mile. M: It's over a mile away? W: Oh, at least. Now, we get in a bridge, go straight over. M: Er, ha. W: Then a little way passed, you'll see a sign "Hill Farm" on your left. M: And that's finally it? W: Yes. M: Got it. Err, you're not driving that way, are you? W: Sorry. M: Well, Now no homing asking. Thanks for your help!
target: How far away is Hill Farm? (A) Nearly a mile. (B) Just one mile. (C) More than a mile.

input: M: How are the restaurant prices here? W: Oh. It's not cheap but not very expensive. You can have a nice lunch for about $6.30.
target: What does the woman think of the restaurant prices here? (A) Fair. (B) Cheap. (C) Expensive.

input: W: Those birds love my yard. See? They are probably looking for worms. M: Yeah, they are lucky they can find meals in lots of places. We have to go to the grocery store to buy our food. W: True, but I wouldn't want to eat what they do, even if it's free.
target: What are the speakers mainly talking about? (A) Birds. (B) The woman's yard. (C) Food from the grocery store.

input: W: Oh, my God! It's 2:05. M: Come on. Let's go. The plane leaves in ten minutes.
target: When will the plane leave? (A) 2:05. (B) 2:10. (C) 2:15.

input: M: What do you think of cloning? W: No doubt it's a great invention. But if it's not properly handled, it may have some side effects. M: What do scientists say about it? W: They also have different opinions.
target: What does the woman think of cloning? (A) It has no side effect at all. (B) It should be strictly forbidden. (C) It may cause trouble for humans.

input: W: You took an optional course this semester didn't you? How is it going? M: Terrible. It seems like the more the professor talks the less I understand.
target: How does the man feel about the course? (A) He wishes to have more courses like it. (B) He finds it hard to follow the teacher. (C) He wishes the teacher would talk more.

input: M: You'll need 36 credit hours to get an M. A. degree. Fifteen must be from the English Department and fifteen from the Education Department. For the remaining six credit hours, you can either write a thesis or take two more selected courses. W: Right now, this is very confusing to me, but I'm sure I'll know what to do as I learn more about it.
target: What are they talking about? (A) Getting extra credits. (B) The requirements of an M. A. degree. (C) The credit hours required for an M. A. degree.

input: F: When will the concert finish? M: Well...it starts at six thirty, and will lasts three hours.
target: When will the concert finish? (A) Six thirty. (B) Nine thirty. (C) Seven thirty.

input: M: When did you buy that new necklace? W: I didn't buy it. It was a gift.
target: How much did the necklace cost the woman? (A) none. (B) One dollar. (C) 100 dollars.

input: M: What's all that noise? It sounds as if it's coming from next door, The Nelson aren't back yet, are they? W: I don't think so. It must be the window cleaner working upstairs.
target: Where does the woman think the noise is coming from? (A) From upstairs. (B) From next door. (C) From the Nelsons' house.

input: W: Richard worked as an editor for two years. Then he became a journalist. After that, he began to write novels. M: Yes. And now he is already very famous for his works.
target: What is Richard famous for? (A) Editing. (B) Reporting. (C) Writing.

input: W: Jimmy, take this umbrella with you. M: Why? It's a fine day, isn't it? W: Yes, but the weatherman said it's going to rain this afternoon.
target: What will the weather be like this afternoon? (A) Sunny. (B) Windy. (C) Rainy.

input: F: Do you like spring best, Jim? M: No, I like summer best because I can go swimming in summer.
target: Which is Jim's favorite season? (A) Spring. (B) Summer. (C) Winter.

input: F: Look at the workers there with thick glasses over their eyes. M: Don't you know they can keep their eyes safe?
target: Why do the workers wear thick glasses? (A) Because they can't see. (B) Because the weather is very hot. (C) Because they will keep their eyes safe.

input: W: Do you like fried chicken? M: Yes, it's my favorite dish. What about you? W: I don't care much for chicken. I prefer seafood. M: But seafood is expensive. I should say.
target: What are they talking about? (A) The taste of food. (B) The cost of food. (C) The food they like and dislike.

input: W: I'll be back this evening. John can't take me to the bus station in his car, so I'll walk down and get a later one than usual. M: OK. I'll wait for you.
target: How will the woman get back home? (A) By taxi. (B) By bus. (C) On foot.

input: A: I like English better than math. B: Me, too.
target: What subject do they like better? (A) English. (B) Chinese. (C) Math.

input: M: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two? W: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us? M: Sure. W: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here? M: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern. W: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby? M: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable. W: It sounds nice. Thank you very much for your help. M: That's all right.
target: What does the woman prefer? (A) A cheap hotel. (B) A modern hotel. (C) An expensive hotel.

input: W: Were you hurt in the accident? M: I was shocked at the time, but wasn't hurt at all. My bike was totally damaged though.
target: What do we know about the man? (A) He has got a heart attack. (B) He was unharmed. (C) He was badly hurt.

input: M: Sally, I guess you must have had a good time in Europe during your vacation. W: Not really, actually.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She didn't have a vacation. (B) She liked her vacation very much. (C) She didn't enjoy her holiday.

input: M: I'm sorry that I completely forgot our appointment yesterday. W: Never mind. So did I.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She was late for the appointment. (B) She didn't wait for the man. (C) She also forgot the appointment.

input: F: It's 7:30, are you leaving now, Jim? M: No, I'm going to wait another twenty minutes.
target: When will Jim leave? (A) At 7:30. (B) At 7:40. (C) At 7:50.

input: W: What did you do? M: I used to be a reporter. W: An interesting job, wasn't it? M: Yes, it was interesting. But I got no free time, even on weekends.
target: How does the man feel about being a reporter? (A) He doesn't like it because it kept him busy. (B) He doesn't like it because it is uninteresting. (C) He likes the job very much.

input: M: Johnson worked as a salesman for five years. Then he became a newspaperman. After that he started a company himself. W: I know. And he's quite successful.
target: What is Johnson's occupation now? (A) He is a salesman. (B) He is a newspaperman. (C) He is a manager.

input: W: Thank goodness! We have finished the final exams at last. M: Yeah, and in a month we'll begin a new life in college.
target: What will these people do in a month? (A) Go to college. (B) Begin a new term in a middle school. (C) Find a job.

input: W: I've been thinking about how I could teach my children to be more loving. M: It sounds like a job for you and your husband. How about if I give you some vacation time? You could take a family trip and talk more with your kids.

input: W: Tom, who won the basketball game yesterday? M: We won by 50 to 36.
