input: W: Look at that big field of corn. And there's a farm with some beautiful houses. M: You really get to know the country when you go by bus, don't you?
target: Where did the conversation most probably take place? (A) In a corn field. (B) At a bus station. (C) On a bus.

input: M: Hello, Jane. Did you have a good journey? F: Not bad, thanks. The train was a bit crowded, but at least we arrived on time.
target: What do we know from this dialogue? (A) The man thinks his journey was very good. (B) The man thinks his journey was too bad. (C) The man thinks his journey was just all so.

input: M: Could you give me your office phone number or fax number so that we can contact each other more often? W: But I've been trying to find a new job in another company. You see, I've worked here for 3 years without a raise. That's unfair to me.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She don't have a fax machine. (B) She may quit her present job soon. (C) She is tired of her present job.

input: W: I have something important to talk to Mr. Robert. But I can't find him. M: Oh. The Roberts family went to Washington for their holiday.
target: Where is the Roberts family? (A) We don't know. (B) They are on holiday. (C) They went to Beijing three days ago.

input: M: I had a hard time getting through this novel. W: I share your feeling. Who can remember the names of 35 different characters?
target: What does the woman imply? (A) She has learned a lot from the novel. (B) She also found the plot difficult to follow. (C) She usually has difficulty remembering names.

input: M: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer? W: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas. M: Why? W: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it. M: Nobody to take care of her? W: My father travels a lot to many countries and he is doing business in Dubai now. I have to do a lot for my mom at home. M: Oh, I see. You are very considerate.
target: Why does the man sound surprised? (A) Lily rejected a job offer. (B) Lily was absent from school. (C) Lily turned down a scholarship.

input: W: I've got a letter from my sister. It's so badly written that I can hardly make out what exactly she was [tying to say. M: Maybe you should call her up to find out what's troubling her.
target: According to the conversation, the woman's sister ________. (A) was probably upset (B) bad little education (C) always writes like that

input: M: It seems we'll have another fine day tomorrow. Let's go to the seaside. W: OK, but we'll have to leave very early, or else we'll get cut in the traffic.
target: What does the woman suggest? (A) They go to the seaside. (B) They set off early. (C) They go sightseeing.

input: W: What're you doing? M: Reading The Joy Luck Club. W: What's it about? M: It's about a group of American-born Chinese women.
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) A book. (B) An American. (C) A club.

input: M: When will you be arriving? W: Friday afternoon, July 9th.
target: When will the woman arrive? (A) July 9th. (B) June 19th. (C) April 19th.

input: M: Can you tell me how to make vegetable soup? W: I have a recipe that my mother gave me.
target: What will the man probably do next? (A) Ask the woman for some vegetables. (B) Borrow the soup recipe. (C) Call the woman's mother.

input: M: Can you believe I had to pay $ 30 for a haircut at Sadermale. W: You should try the place where I go. It's only 15, but it takes a while to get an appointment.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She needs another haircut soon. (B) She thinks it worthwhile to try Sadermale's. (C) She knows a less expensive place for a haircut.

input: M: What did you think of the mid-term exam? W: I was expecting it to be easy, but at the end of the first hour, I was still on the first page. I hardly had time to get to the last question.
target: What is the probable result for her exam? (A) It's OK. (B) Poor. (C) Excellent.

input: W: Our daughter hasn't written to us for nearly two months. M: She must be very busy with her studies.
target: What does their daughter do? (A) She is a doctor. (B) She is a teacher. (C) She is a student.

input: M: The floor looks super clean. Did you call the cleaning company? W: Nope. My foot is broken. I stay at home. So I did it myself. M: With a broken foot? Was that a good idea? W: Don't worry, Dave. M: You could have called Brenda. She would have done it for you. W: I'm not asking your little sister to clean my floors, Dave. Anyway, it wasn't as hard as you think. I have been using a Roomba recently. M: Oh, that cleaning robot? I'm jealous, Sandra. I wanted one, but I didn't have 500 extra dollars. W: I know. They're so expensive. I got mine from my boss when I was Employee of the Year two years ago.
target: What is the conversation mainly about? (A) Sandra's foot. (B) Cleaning the floor. (C) Housekeeping costs.

input: M: Are you really leaving for Hongkong tomorrow morning? W: Yeah, I guess so. I got the air tickets. I can't wait to see Bill there.
target: What is the woman going to do? (A) She's flying to Hong Kong. (B) She's going to buy an air ticket. (C) She's going to say good-bye to Bill.

input: W: Where's Cecilia, Mark? M: I'm not sure. She finishes school at 3. Maybe she went to Joyce's. She knows she has to come home before 5. W: It's 5:30 now. M: Maybe she forgot her watch. W: Well, someone has to wash the dishes. The kitchen's a mess. M: I can go to Joyce's. I know her address. W: That's OK. We don't need her. You can wash the dishes.
target: Where are the two speakers? (A) At the store. (B) At home. (C) At school.

input: Bill: Hey, this is Bill. I'm sorry I'm not in. Just leave a message. [Beep] Hank: Hey Bill. This is Hank. I'm just calling to let you know that I'll be a little late to the game tomorrow night. I have to work a few extra hours to finish a report. I should wrap things up sometime between seven and eight though. Oh, then I'm planning on dropping by Lisa's house for about an hour since she's been sick recently. And, uh, one more thing. I'll swing by my house to pick up some food for the game. See you then.
target: What will take place at Bill's house tomorrow? (A) a party (B) a game (C) a dance

input: W: You must be pretty excited about your trip to Europe. When do you leave? M: In just three weeks. And I'm excited! But there are still a few things I need to do before I go.
target: What do we learn from the conversation? (A) The man needs three weeks to do something before leaving for Europe. (B) The man is excited about his trip to Europe. (C) The woman is leaving for Europe in just three weeks.

input: M: Should we go out or eat in tonight? W: I am too tired to do any cooking.
target: What does the woman imply? (A) She is not hungry. (B) She wants to dine out. (C) She is not tired.

input: M: I'd like to apply for the position you advertised in the paper. W: A good knowledge of French and Spanish is a must.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The advertised jobs are in France and Spain. (B) French and Spanish are necessary for the job. (C) The notice appeared in French and Spanish newspapers.

input: M: I thought that the chair cost 50 dollars. W: It used to, but the price has gone up 15 dollars. M: Well, that's more than I can afford, I'm afraid.
target: What's the price of the chair? (A) $15. (B) $50. (C) $65.

input: W: What is the most interesting thing for you in the summer vacation, Jack? M: The evening party, of course. We danced around an open fire, ate a lot of meat and drank a lot of beer.
target: The most interesting thing for Jack during the summer vacation is ______. (A) dancing (B) the evening party (C) drinking beer

input: W: Hello. Milton Hotel. Can I help you? M: I want a reservation. Can I have it now? W: Of course. What kind of taste do you like for your dinner? M: I prefer Chinese dishes. W: Would you like to sit in a smoking section, a non-smoking section or an open one? M: A non-smoking section. W: I'm awfully sorry, but we haven't got the section left now. Would you like to wait for a while? M: Not at all. An open section will do, too. W: OK. See you then.
target: What is the probable relationship between the speakers? (A) Waitress and customer. (B) Manager and assistant. (C) Employer and employee.

input: M: Why you don't like going to the cinema? W: Well, there are too many problems. For example, when a film is popular, the cinema is rather crowded. M: Is that all? W: No, the worst is the people - children running up and down, people chatting endlessly, and so on. So, I'd rather stay home and wait to see the films when they are shown on TV. M: Then you may see the films a bit later than other people. W: Yes, but I'll be more comfortable in the quietness of my living room. M: Well, I prefer seeing films at the cinema as soon as they come out.
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) New films. (B) Popular cinemas. (C) Film-seeing habits.

input: M: How many students took the exam last Saturday? W: Well, let me see. I believe that we had twenty-five from the Middle East and fifteen from Latin America.
target: How many students took the exam? (A) Forty students. (B) Fifty students. (C) Twenty-five students.

input: M: I am running out of coins doing my laundry. W: That's too bad.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She saw the man run out. (B) She thought the man's laundry was done badly. (C) She was sorry the man couldn't finish his laundry.

input: M: Hello, may I speak to Andrew, please? W: Oh, hold on a second, I'll check for you.
target: Is Andrew in? (A) Yes, he is. (B) No, he isn't. (C) We are not sure.

input: F: Would you mind turning off the radio? M: Sure, of course I will.
target: Will the man mind doing what the woman's words? (A) No. (B) We don't know. (C) Yes, he will.

input: M: Can I borrow your pen? Mine is out of ink. W: Sorry, I don't have a second pen. Would a pencil do?
target: What did the woman mean (A) She could let the man have her pen. (B) She had no pen herself. (C) She could offer him a pencil.

input: M: What kind of room do you want, single or double? F: A single room.
target: Where is the woman now? (A) In a restaurant. (B) In a hotel. (C) In a supermarket.

input: M: Have you found your key? F: Yes, I've found it under the table.
target: Where has the key been found? (A) Under the table. (B) Under the desk. (C) On the table.

input: M: What do you think of Richard? W: He always helps us whenever we are in trouble.
target: What kind of person is Richard? (A) A trouble-maker. (B) A selfish person. (C) A helpful person.

input: W: Hi, Jeff, it's Marina. I'm sorry but my computer is not working. Could you get someone to check it? M: Don't worry. I'll ask an engineer to check it for you, is that OK?
target: What does the woman ask the man to do? (A) Tell her what the problem is. (B) Repair the computer for her. (C) Send someone to help her.

input: W: Er... It's rather hot here. Do yon mind my opening the window? M: Oh... No... Not at all.
target: What will the woman do? (A) Open the window. (B) Close the window. (C) Keep on talking.

input: M: Do you want your television repaired? W: Yes, but not by the man you suggested. M: Why not? The repairmen are very good and the charges are so reasonable. W: That may be, but I couldn't find the place. M: But you couldn't miss it. I told you it is at the first right after the railroad bridge. W: I took that. I went to the end of the road. There is no such place. M: Wait a minute. Perhaps it is the second right. Yes, I think it is. W: I should have known, whenever someone says "You can't miss it", you can be sure that you won't find it.
target: Whom do you think the woman was angry with? (A) The man. (B) The repairman. (C) The shopkeeper.

input: W: Did you watch the game yesterday? M: I wanted to do, but Marie was watching a movie on Channel 5, so I watched it with her. You know Marie, she can't stand football.
target: Why didn't the man watch the game? (A) Because Maria doesn't like football. (B) Because Maria fell ill. (C) Because he didn't have the time.

input: W: What can I do for you? M: Well, has anyone turned in a brown leather wallet? Mine seems to be lost and it has my driver's license in it. W: Anything else in the wallet? M: Yes, some family pictures. W: I think one like that was brought in this morning. Wait here just a minute please.
target: What will the woman probably do? (A) She will ask to see the man's driver's license. (B) She will sell the man a new leather wallet. (C) She will show the man a wallet.

input: M: I have no idea if they will come to the party or not. W: Don't worry. We have enough food for all of them.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She thinks the food is not enough for all of the people. (B) There is plenty of food for all the people. (C) She will cancel the party since nobody comes.

input: W: Tiger Cinema. What can I do for you? M: Yes. Could you tell me what time the film starts? W: The film? Ten past nine tomorrow.
target: What time will the film start? (A) Tonight. (B) Tomorrow. (C) Tomorrow evening

input: W: You'd better fasten your seat belt, sir. We'll be coming onto land soon. M: Oh, thank you. Landing is the best part of the flight.
target: Where are the two speakers? (A) On a ship. (B) On a train. (C) On a plane.

input: W: I hear the mayor is planning a tax reduction. Have you any details? M: Yes, it was one of his campaign promises and he's seriously trying to make it a reality.
target: What can be learned about taxes from the conversation? (A) Taxes will increase. (B) Taxes will be higher. (C) Taxes will be lower.

input: M: Hi, Jane. I'd like to discuss something with you. Do you have a minute? W: Sure. I've just got out of my eleven o'clock class. I don't have another class until this afternoon. M: Good. Listen, I've just received an e-mail from the computer centre. They are looking for students to help with the work of the school website this summer. They need two assistants. They asked me if I knew anyone that might be interested. I thought you might like to consider the job. W: Sounds interesting. I can type, but I don't have a lot of experience. M: Well, I don't think any special experience or knowledge is necessary. And with your interests in computers and the Internet, I think you would be good for the job. Also they're paying good money. What do you think? W: It sounds like a great chance to get some experience. Thanks for thinking of me.
target: What are the two speakers talking about? (A) A part-time job. (B) A computer lesson. (C) A summer holiday plan.

input: W: What's new with you, Jack? M: Well, I met a really nice woman. We've been going out for three months and things look good now.
target: Who is the man talking about now? (A) His girlfriend. (B) His sister. (C) His mother.

input: W: There were more than a hundred people at Kate's birthday party. How come she's got so many friends? M: It's really no surprise. You know she was popular even when she was a child.
target: What does the man imply about Kate? (A) She expected more people at her party. (B) She has always enjoyed great popularity. (C) She threw a surprise party for her friend.

input: M: I hope it will be fine tomorrow. I'm going beating with Tom. W: Oh, I think it will be fine. Because I heard it on the radio.
target: What are the two speakers talking about? (A) A fine boat. (B) Their friend Tom. (C) The weather.

input: W: I shall have to go into hospital some time to have an operation on my leg. M: Are you on the waiting list? W: Yes, I've been waiting for three years.
target: How long has the woman been on the waiting list? (A) Three days. (B) Three years. (C) Thirteen months.

input: M: What kind of music do you like? W: I like classical music. Do you? M: Well, you see, classical music always sends me to sleep.
target: What does the man think of classical music? (A) He does not like it at all. (B) He prefers it to other music. (C) He enjoys it at bedtime.

input: W: Hi, Michael. I'm awfully sorry for having kept you waiting. It's... M: Well, but it doesn't matter. That's just fine. I've looked after myself, you see. I've had a couple of drinks. W: Ah, I see.
target: What did the man do? (A) Had some drinks. (B) Made a phone call. (C) Looked after the woman.

input: W: I think I will take the half-day tour of the city. M: Why not the whole day?
target: What does the man suggest? (A) Spending more time on sightseeing. (B) Visiting the city with a group. (C) Touring the city on a fine day.

input: M: I've been waiting all week for this concert. The performance is said to be excellent and with a student's discount, the tickets will be really cheap. Student discount W: Ah-huh. I'm afraid I left my Student ID card in the dorm.
target: What does the woman imply? (A) She wants to borrow the man's student ID card. (B) The tickets are less expensive than she expected. (C) She won't be able to get any discount for the ticket.

input: M: I can hardly believe that city has a population of 800,000. W: To be more exact, there are 813,400 people there.
target: What is the population of that city? (A) 800,000. (B) 813,000. (C) 813,400.

input: M: Shall I call a taxi? W: But the grand hotel is only two blocks away. M: Well, you're right.
target: How will the speakers probably go to the hotel? (A) By taxi (B) On foot (C) By bus

input: W: Hi. I'm glad I ran into you. M: Why? What's up? W: Would you like to go climbing this weekend? M: I'm not sure. I promised to help my sister move on Saturday. W: How about Sunday, then? We could start early in the morning. M: I might be able to do that. Let me check and I'll call you up tonight. W: Great! By the way, I won't be home before 10 o'clock. M: Then, how can I reach you? W: I've got an answering machine. You can simply call and leave a message. Your voice will be recorded. M: I hate talking to a machine. It feels strange. W: All right. I'll give you another telephone number. I'll be at my mother's home.
target: What would the woman like to do this weekend? (A) Go climbing. (B) Go shopping. (C) Go fishing.

input: W: Excuse me. This is the address. How do I find it? M: Right. You'll need a street map. Here's one, and I'll show you where it is.
target: What does the woman want to do? (A) Find a place. (B) Buy a map. (C) Get an address.

input: M: We'd better start to eat onions frequently, Linda. W: But you hate onions, don't you? M: Until I learned from a report from today's paper that they protect people from flu and colds. After all, compared with health, taste is not so important.
target: What do we learn about the man? (A) He is health-conscious. (B) He is sensitive to taste. (C) He often catches colds.

input: M: If it rains on Saturday, the party will be ruined. W: What does it matter? We can always hold it indoors.
target: What are the man and woman hoping to do? (A) Repair the other door. (B) Visit some ruins. (C) Give an outdoor party.

input: W: Front desk. Can I help you? M: Yeah, hi, this is Room 327. Is your dining room still open?
target: Where are the two speakers? (A) In a restaurant. (B) In a hotel. (C) In the street.

input: M: What did you do? W: Oh, I burned myself while I was cooking dinner. M: Oh! W: How about you? M: I hurt myself while I was bowling. W: Your back? M: Yes.
target: What happened to the woman? (A) She hurt her leg while bowling. (B) She was burnt while cooking. (C) She hurt her back while bowling.

input: M: Hello. W: Is this Mr. Green's office? M: Yes, it is. W: Is he there? M: I'm sorry, he isn't. He's at a meeting this morning. W: What time will he be back? M: He'll be back after two o'clock but he'll only be in the office for an hour. W: Can I reach him in the conference room? M: I'm sorry, but they aren't taking any calls. Can I take message for you? W: This is Anne Lucas in the accounts office. I would like a word with him, please. M: I can ask him to call you after the meeting. Can I have your number? W: Yes, it's 488-6361. He can reach me there until three o'clock.
target: How long will Mr. Green stay in the office after the meeting? (A) Two hours. (B) One hour. (C) Three hours.

input: M: I want to exercise, but I never seem to find the time. W: Why not do it first thing in the morning? M: Sounds like a good idea.
target: What does the woman suggest? (A) Exercising right after getting up. (B) Not exercising in the morning. (C) Exercising after breakfast.

input: W: You've had a very dangerous life, haven't you, Joe? M: Yes. That's right. W: When was your worst accident? M: Last year. It was during the British Grand Prix. I knocked into a wall. The car was completely destroyed and my left leg was broken. Luckily nobody was killed. W: Is that the only time you've been..., er... close to death? M: No, I had a very frightening experience quite recently. I was frightened to death! I thought I was going to be killed at any moment. W: Really? When was that? M: It was on my way to this studio. I had to drive through London during the lunch hour.
target: What's the man? (A) A film star. (B) A bus driver. (C) A famous racing-driver.

input: W: Listen to me, Joe, the exam is already a thing of the past. Just forget about it. M: That's easier said than done.
target: What can we infer from the conversation? (A) The exam was easier than the previous one. (B) Joe is sure that he will do better in the next exam. (C) Joe probably failed in the exam.

input: M: Hi, Janet, I hear you've just returned from a tour of Australia. Did you get a chance to visit the Sydney Opera House? W: Of course I did. It would be a shame for anyone visiting Australia not to see this unique creation in architecture. Its magnificent beauty is simply beyond description.
target: What do we learn from this conversation? (A) Janet is very much interested in architecture. (B) Janet admires the Sydney Opera House very much. (C) Janet thinks it's a shame for anyone not to visit Australia.

input: M: The students English Club is having a party on Saturday night. Can you come? W: I would like to but I work at a restaurant on weekend.
target: What do we learn from the conversation? (A) Because she has got an appointment. (B) Because she doesn't want to. (C) Because she has to work.

input: W: Well, look at the words. Someone gave this book as a present, and wrote a note on the inside of the front cover. It's dated 1893. Maybe it's worth something. M: Everything on that shelf is worth fifty cents. W: But if this is the signature of someone who is well-known, it might bring a lot more. I hear William Shakespeare's signature is worth about a million dollars. M: Oh? I can hardly read what that one says. Who wrote it? W: The name looks like "Harold Dickson". Wasn't he a politician or something? I'm going to buy this book and see if I can find a name looks like that in the library. M: Good luck. Your poetry book may make you rich, but I think my seventy-five-cent story is a better buy.
target: Where is the conversation taking place? (A) In a second-hand bookstore. (B) In a publisher's office. (C) In a library.

input: W: How long have you been in the army service? M: Twenty-five years. I joined up right after college. W: I have only been in the army for seven years. M: Looks like you have a while to go until retirement.
target: Who are the two speakers? (A) Retired soldiers. (B) College students. (C) Army people.

input: M: Have you heard that all the international flights have been canceled because of the weather? W: No, I've been in the meeting-hall all day. M: Unfortunately, I found it out while waiting for the flight to New York.
target: Where did the man get the news that the flight had been canceled? (A) At the airport. (B) At the meeting. (C) At the international flat.

input: W: Excuse me. I'd like to buy a desk for my little son. I don't have any particular brand in mind, but it should be less than 50 dollars. M: OK. We have a large selection of small desks for young children.
target: What is the woman's concern when buying a desk? (A) The brand. (B) The price. (C) The size.

input: M: Where are you from? F: Northern Canada.
target: What nationality is the woman? (A) Canada. (B) America. (C) England.

input: W: Did you get the injury playing football, Jim? M: Yes. One of the boys kicked my foot instead of the ball. W: The best thing for you to do is to rest your leg for 48 hours. M: When can I go back to school? W: You can go back in 4 days, but you'll need to avoid sports for a month.
target: How did Jim get hue? (A) He was kicked by a boy. (B) He was hit by a football. (C) He fell down on the ground.

input: M: Excuse me? But is there a bus going to the zoo? W: Well, you have the right stop. but the bus doesn't go straight to the zoo. You have to transfer to a No. 37 bus. M: Where do I change for No. 57 then? W: I think you get off at Time Street. M: How far is it away from here? W: Only 4 stops. Don't worry. I will get off there too. M: OK, I will follow you. W: Are you a stranger here? M: Yes. I came only a few clays ago. This is my first visit to this city. W: How do you like the city? M: Well. it's hard to say. I will see more before I can say anything. But the people I meet here are all kind to me. W: I hope you like the city soon.
target: What is the man going to do according to the conversation? (A) The man is going to follow the woman. (B) The man is going to take two buses. (C) The man is going to get on a No.57 bus.

input: M: Lucy, you are late for class again. W: Sorry. I study for the math test last night and went to bed late. M: Well, I see. Come earlier next time.
target: Where are they talking? (A) In the library. (B) In the classroom. (C) In the theater.

input: W: Hi, Bill. I haven't seen a film for half a year. Do you have some free time to go to the cinema with me this weekend? M: Sure. But I don't have any information about the recent films. What about you? W: Well, my workmate tells me that Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone will be on. M: What's that? W: I don't know. It is said that kids like it a lot. M: Perhaps you can take our son there. It's boring for me to sit there for two hours. W: Oh, you're that kind of man. Um, a violent film called The Most Wanted will also be on at the same time. Maybe you can come with us. M: That's a clever idea. I like American films very much. We can go to the same cinema and come home together, but watch different films.
target: What's the relationship between the two speakers? (A) Husband and wife. (B) Classmates. (C) A teacher and his students.

input: W: Jack is younger than Kate. M: But he is older than Mike.
target: Who is the youngest of the three? (A) Jack. (B) Mike. (C) Kate.

input: W: Tony, there is an interesting new movie in town. We really must go and see it. M: OK, but let's have supper first. I'm quite hungry.
target: What does the man propose to do first? (A) Have a meal. (B) See the movie. (C) Get the tickets.

input: W: Tom said he would come to repair our solar heater when he had time. M: He often says he is willing to help, but he never seems to have time.
target: What does the man imply about Tom? (A) He is not a good mechanic. (B) He doesn't keep his word. (C) He spends his spare time doing repairs.

input: W: We'll have to hurry if we want to finish this project on time. M: I'll say we will!
target: What does the man mean? (A) He wants to talk about the project. (B) He thinks the project is fine. (C) He agrees with the woman.

input: W: Don't turn the dishwasher on! The baby just fell asleep. I need a break! I'm exhausted from cooking soup and baking cookies all morning. M: Oh! I'll run it later, then. Let's sit outside and read while she sleeps.
target: How does the woman feel? (A) Surprised. (B) Tired. (C) Relaxed.

input: W: I hear you did some serious shopping this past weekend. M: Yeah, the speakers of my old stereo finally gave out and there was no way to repair them.
target: What did the man do over the weekend? (A) He got his speakers fixed. (B) He went shopping with the woman. (C) He listened to some serious music.

input: M: The teacher called off the lecture. W: Oh, really? His student John must be disappointed at this news.
target: Who is John? (A) Teacher. (B) Student. (C) Nurse.

input: W: Are you looking forward to going back home? M: Not really. The weather here agrees with me.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He thinks the weather here is bad (B) He wants to go back home (C) He likes the weather here

input: W: Has Jones got up? M: Yes, he has been up since six. W: Oh, I see. He has been up for half an hour. M: That's right.
target: At what time did the dialogue happen? (A) At 7:00. (B) At 6:30. (C) At 6:00.

input: M: Is it still raining? W: Is it raining? Look at my clothes--they're wet.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She's looking for her raincoat. (B) She's wearing her clothes. (C) She got caught in the rain.

input: W: I'm sorry, Mr Wilson. I got up early but the bus was late. M: Your bus is always late, Jane.
target: What does the man mean? (A) Jane used the same excuse again. (B) Jane stayed up too late last night. (C) Jane always gets up early.

input: W: I'm losing my sleep. I feel tired and sleepy all the time. I've got to do something about it. M: I'm so sorry for you. But what are you going to do? W: I want to move out of the dorm and rent a small flat. M: That's a good idea. It will be much more convenient for you. W: But I need your help. M: How? To find one person for you? W: Yes M: I'll sleep on it tonight and tell you my decision tomorrow. OK?
target: What's wrong with the woman? (A) She has caught a cold. (B) She has a headache. (C) She feels tired and sleepy all the time.

input: M: Why don't you go to a show or something tonight? W: As a matter of fact, I thought Judy might like to go to a concert. M: Let's have a look and see what's on... You might try the concert at the Festival Hall. W: That sounds nice.
target: What is the man doing? (A) Asking for help. (B) Making suggestions. (C) Asking for permission.

input: F: Peter, is it raining outside? M: No, but the sun is behind the clouds.
target: What is the weather like outside? (A) Sunny. (B) Rainy (C) Cloudy.

input: M: Hello! May 1 speak to Mrs. Arnold? W: Speaking. M: This is Sparkle Company. You are one of the lucky housewives chosen to receive our free soap. W: That's very nice of you. But I'd rather go on using what I've always used. Thanks just the same.
target: Where is the woman? (A) In a soap factory. (B) In her house. (C) At an information desk.

input: M: I still can't understand, Betty. Why are you working for Smith's company? W: He offered me a job as a typist and I need the job.
target: What did Smith offer her? (A) Smith offered her a computer. (B) Smith offered her a room. (C) Smith offered her a job as a typist.

input: W: Do you have the seminar schedule with you? I'd like to find out the topic for Friday. M: I gave it to my friend, but there should be copies available in the library. I can pick one up for you.
target: What does the man promise to do? (A) To get the seminar schedule for the woman. (B) To make a copy of the schedule for his friend. (C) To find out more about the topic for the seminar.

input: F: The red bag is $10 and the blue one is $5. M: I'll take the cheaper one.
target: Which bag did he buy? (A) The red one. (B) The big one. (C) The blue one.

input: M: Hello, I'm John. Nice to meet you! W: Nice to meet you, too! I'm Natasha. Are you British? M: No, I'm an American. Where are you from? W: I am from Russia.
target: Where is the woman from? (A) Britain. (B) Russia. (C) America.

input: W: Have we agreed where we're going to meet John on Sunday? M: Well, I talked to the others and nobody seemed to have any idea where they wanted to go. W: I thought we were going to that restaurant.., what was it? M: ... the McDonald's at the end of Beijing Road--I suggested it a long time ago. W: Well--I think we should agree on that. M: OK, shall I phone the others now? W: No, thanks. It is better for me to do that!
target: What does the woman want the man to do? (A) Change a decision. (B) Make a phone call. (C) Suggest a place to meet.

input: W: Yes, sir. May I help you? M: I have a reservation for tonight. John Durgin. W: Just a moment, please. Let me check. That's right. You have a reservation for a two-room suite for tonight. M: I'm afraid there's been a mistake. I only reserve a single room, not a suite. W: I'm sorry, Mr. Durgin, but this is what is available. Your reservation arrived too late to have a single. There's a large conference in town this week and we're full up. M: Well, if that's the way it is, I'll have to take it. W: Please sign the register here. Your suite is 526. M: Thank you. W: The lift is on your right, sir, and I'll have your bags sent up in a moment. M: Fine, thanks.
target: Where does this conversation take place? (A) In a restaurant. (B) In a hotel. (C) At a conference.

input: W: I can't find the arrival times for the New York to Boston trains on this schedule. M: Look for New York in the left hand column and follow it across until you find the hour listed in the Boston column.
target: What is the woman looking at? (A) Pictures of the trains from Boston to New York. (B) A map of New York. (C) A timetable.

input: F: Excuse me. Is it raining outside? M: No. The rain has stopped. It's cloudy now.
target: Is it raining outside? (A) Yes. (B) No. (C) Not mentioned.

input: W: Would you mind if we discuss our plan before dinner? M: Not at all. I certainly don't want to talk about it over dinner.
target: When will they probably discuss the plan? (A) Before dinner. (B) After lunch. (C) Over dinner.

input: W: Hello, Jim. Where are you going? M: To the cinema. What about coming with me? W: No, thanks. I'm going home. My friend's expecting me. M: What a pity! I believe it's a very good film. W: Do you go to the cinema a lot? M: Once a week. Most nights I sit at home and watch TV. W: Oh, I see. By the way, where are you going for your holidays this year? M: I don't know yet. My wife's going to her mother's for a couple of weeks. She lives by the sea, you know. W: Oh, does she? That's convenient. M: Yes, but I want to go to the country. W: Don't you like the sea? M: Yes, very much. But I need peace and quiet when I'm on holiday.
target: Where is Jim going? (A) To the cinema. (B) To the hospital. (C) To the shop.

input: M: Would you like to come over and study tonight, Janet? W: Oh, I'm sorry, Tom. I forgot to tell you that my parents are in town and want to take me to the concert tonight.
target: Where will Janet probably go tonight? (A) To study. (B) To the concert. (C) To town.

input: W: Could you have my car ready at 5:00 please? M: Sure. Have you read the damage?
target: Where did the conversation take place? (A) In a car repair shop. (B) In a market. (C) In a parking lot.

input: M: Hurry, there is a bus coming. W: Why run? There will be another one in two or three minutes.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The next bus is coming soon. (B) The bus will wait a few minutes at thestop. (C) There are only two or three passengers waiting for the bus.

input: W: Can you take me to the Fairyland Restaurant quickly? I'm already five minutes late. M: I'll try. But the traffic is so heavy. It will take at least another 15 minutes.
target: What is the man? (A) A taxi driver. (B) A policeman. (C) A restaurant waiter.

input: M: Cathy, is it raining? F: No. But I see some clouds.
target: What's the weather like? (A) It's raining. (B) It's cloudy. (C) It's beautiful.

input: M: How do most students find a job after they graduate? W: They usually look for a job by searching the Want Ads in the newspapers.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) Most students would like to work for a newspaper. (B) Most students find a job by reading advertisements. (C) Most students find it hard to get a job after they graduate.

input: W: If I go to Paris, will you meet me there? We can visit my cousin's new home. M: Well, I had intended to, but I changed my mind at the last moment.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He didn't have enough money to go to the concert. (B) He arrived too late to hear the concert. (C) He altered his plans suddenly.

input: M: What's in that bag over there? W: I bought some apples, peaches, pears and grapes.
target: What's in that big bag? (A) Vegetables. (B) Meats. (C) Fruits.

input: W: Hello. This is Amy. M: Hello, Amy. This is Tom. W: Yes. What can I do for you? M: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me? W: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's a little late. Why don't you go there by car? M: My car is being repaired now. I have to go there by train. W: Do you think you have enough time? M: Yes. I'll try it. Thank you. Bye.
target: What does Tom make the phone call for? (A) Saying hello. (B) Repairing his car. (C) Asking about the train time.

input: M: I have to go to the library to prepare for the coming test. W: That's too bad. I wish that you could go with me to the cinema.
target: Where is the man going? (A) The classroom. (B) The library. (C) The cinema.

input: M: Excuse me, but the class has lasted for an hour already. F: OK...Now let's take a short break.
target: How long had the class last? (A) An hour. (B) Too short. (C) We don't know.

input: M: The famous novel writer's new book is coming out in July. W: We probably won't be able to find a copy until September.
target: When will the writer's book be published? (A) In the winter. (B) In July. (C) In September.

input: W: Can you come to the concert with me this weekend? Or do you have to prepare for exams? M: I still have a lot to do, but maybe a break would do me good.
target: What will the man probably do? (A) Prepare for his exams. (B) Catch up on his work. (C) Attend the concert.

input: M: Ann, do you and your husband plan to have many children? W: Only two. It's expensive to have a big family now.
target: What do we know about the woman? (A) She has already had two children. (B) She does not want to have any children. (C) She does not want to have a big family.

input: M: Shall we go to the concert this evening? I have two tickets. W: Oh, sorry. I'm afraid I can't. I'm seeing my dad off at the railway station at 8:00.
target: What will the woman do this evening? (A) Meet her dad at the railway station. (B) Say good-bye to her dad at the railway station. (C) Go to another city together with her dad.

input: M: How do you like this brown dress? It looks great on you. W: I think it's a bit too heavy. Since it's getting warmer at this time of the year, I want something light. What other kinds of material do you have? M: We have silk and cotton dresses. A cotton dress is suitable in spring. We have many different kinds. What color would you like? I think yellow or green would be good choices for you. W: I would like the white one.
target: What is the probable relationship between the two speakers? (A) Salesman and customer. (B) Husband and wife. (C) Teacher and student.

input: M: How did you enjoy the film yesterday evening? W: Well, most of the people left the cinema before it was over.
target: How was the film? (A) It was interesting. (B) It wasn't interesting at all. (C) It was great.

input: W: Now that you are on the business, what's your advice for someone to become a fashion designer? M: Go to school. I mean it. Find a good school and learn as much as you can.
target: What does the man mean? (A) Fashion designing is a booming business. (B) School learning is a must for fashion designers. (C) He hopes to attend a good fashion school.

input: M: I'd like to buy a pair of shoes. W: Please go up on the third floor.
target: Where does the conversation most likely take place? (A) At a shop. (B) In a restaurant. (C) At home.

input: M: Have you seen Mr. Li? W: No, I haven't. Is he looking for me? M: Yes, he is. He wants to talk to you. W: To me? About what? M: There's an opening in the sales department. He wants to talk to you about it. W: Oh, that's great! What kind of this job is it? M: He hasn't told me exactly. But it will be a better job than this. W: Thank you for your help. M: Don't thank me yet! He hasn't talked to you and he hasn't chosen you for the job yet. W: I know.
target: Who is Mr. Li? (A) The woman's co-worker. (B) The woman's secretary. (C) The woman's boss.

input: M: I am glad you could come. I have been looking forward to meeting you. I have heard so much about you. W: It's so nice to meet you. You have just moved here, haven't you?
target: Which of the following is right? (A) The man is the woman's old friend. (B) The woman knew the man before. (C) The man knows something about the woman.

input: W: What a magnificent temple! M: Oh, yes, it is amazing. I can't believe it's over 1,000 years old. W: Let's go in and have a look inside.
target: What are the speakers probably doing? (A) Having a visit. (B) Looking at a picture. (C) Talking about history.

input: W: Good evening, sir, madam. A table for two? M: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us? W: Sure. What can I do for you? M: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here? W: Yes, there are some hotels in the street. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern. M: Do you think there're any inexpensive ones nearby? We're leaving tomorrow morning. W: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find a grey building on the right side. It's a traditional family style hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable. M: It sounds nice. Thank you very much for your help. W: That's all right.
target: What are the man and woman looking for? (A) A comfortable hotel. (B) A modern hotel. (C) An inexpensive hotel.

input: M: Can you speak louder, Liu Ying? So that everyone can hear you. W: Yes, sir.
target: Where are they talking probably? (A) At home. (B) In the classroom. (C) In the street.

input: W: Mr. Cooper! I tried to make my own colors based on what you taught us in class yesterday. It wasn't easy, though. W: Can you see it here? I wanted to make purple, but I didn't use quite enough blue. It turned out just kind of gray and boring. M: Well, I think it turned out great anyway! This is part of the fun of painting - discovering what you can do with a little imagination, taking some risks, and trying to do new things. W: Thanks for the encouragement. M: Sometimes the most beautiful things result from artistic accidents. And I'd say the same is true of almost all interesting things.
target: What did Mr. Cooper teach the woman to do yesterday? (A) Make different colors. (B) Avoid artistic accidents. (C) Use her imagination more in her art.

input: M: Look at the time. I'm going to miss my last bus. W: Don't worry. I'll drive you to the stop. And if the bus has already left, I can get you to your home.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She will help the man get home. (B) She has to go home soon. (C) The bus will not leave very soon.

input: M: When do you want to leave for that seaside town, Martha? W: I'm not sure yet, but maybe we should leave on Friday after work. It's a long drive, but I'd rather get there late Friday than midday Saturday. We have three days off this time, after all. M: How long is it? W: Five or six hours. M: So you leave at 4:30 right after work and you will be there around 9:00 or 10:00? W: I suppose so. And we could still have a good night's sleep. M: What are you going to take? W: Mostly shorts and T-shirts. M: You don't think it's going to be a bit cold at night at the seaside? W: Maybe. I'm going to take a sweater or a light coat--just in case. M: Hope you have a good time there.
target: What is the woman going to do? (A) Attend a party. (B) Take a holiday. (C) Go on a business trip.

input: W: Only three more months to go, so what're you going to do after your graduation, Simon? M: My father is going to give me a job in his company. I'll probably work there about a year. So I can learn the basics. W: And what're you doing after that? M: Well, after that, I'm going back to college and get my degree in business. W: That sounds very nice.
target: What is the man now? (A) A university student (B) A company clerk (C) A businessman

input: M: Lucy, can you tell me when Linda will get here? W: I'm not sure, but she is supposed to be here at ten to nine.
target: When should Linda get here? (A) At 8:50. (B) At 9:00. (C) At 10:00.

input: W: Today's November 15th. It's almost time for Thanks giving. M: When is Thanksgiving Day? W: It's celebrated on the fourth Thursday in November. What are your plans for it? M: I have no idea yet. What about you? W: The same as usual. My aunts and uncles and cousins come to our house for dinner. M: Oh, your family get together. What do you usually do? W: We usually have a big meal. My mother cooks turkey. But I prepare the vegetables. My aunts usually bring the pies. The women cook the meal, and the men wash the dishes. M: Really? In my family, when we get together the kids wash the dishes. The whole thing is a lot of work. W: Yes, but I like Thanksgiving. I was out of the country last year, and really missed it. That's one time in the year when families get together. John, if you haven't got any plans, why don't you come to my house to spend the holiday with us? M: Yes, that sounds like a good idea. Thanks a lot.
target: Who spends the holiday with the women's family every year? (A) Her aunts and uncles. (B) Her uncles and cousins. (C) Her aunts and uncles and cousins.

input: M: Well, I'll see you later, Mrs. Todd. My wife is waiting for me to take her shopping. W: I understand. There's a lot to get done at weekends, especially when you two work and the children are small. M: That's right. Jane and I have been talking about visiting you. So when I saw you in the garden, I decided to come over and say hello. W: I'm glad you did. In fact, I should have called on you first, since you have newly moved here. M: By the way, do you need anything from the store? W: No, but thanks for the offer. And thank you for coming over. M: It's a pleasure.
target: What is the relationship between the two speakers? (A) Classmates. (B) Neighbors. (C) Strangers.

input: W: This is Mrs. Starched, my heater is not getting any power and weatherman says the temperature is to fall below zero tonight. Could you get someone to come over and fix it? M: This is the busiest time of the year, but I'll speak to one of our men about going over some time today.
target: Who did Mrs. Starched want to come over? (A) An auto mechanic. (B) An electrician. (C) A carpenter.

input: W: You missed your train today,didn't you? M: No, I didn't. My friend gave me a fide to town.
target: Why didn't the man miss his train? (A) He missed it. (B) He drove his own car to town. (C) His friend drove him to town.

input: W: How is loan feeling today? M: She still has a headache.
target: How is Joan? (A) She is ill. (B) She feels happy. (C) She is sad.

input: W: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock. M: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning. W: Why? What's wrong with you? M: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine? W: Will aspirin do? M: No, aspirin isn't strong enough. W: Then I can do nothing but call for a doctor.
target: Why did the man get to sleep so late? (A) He is doing some medicine research. (B) He talked with his friend. (C) He felt pain.

input: F: Where did you go last Sunday, John? M: I didn't feel well and slept almost the whole day.
target: How did John spend last Sunday? (A) He went to the park. (B) He went to the doctor. (C) He stayed at home.

input: M: I'm thinking about where to go for a bite tonight. Any suggestions, Barbara? W: Well, how about the French restaurant near the KFC? Frankly, I've had enough of our canteen food.
target: What do we learn about the woman? (A) She is tired of the food in the canteen. (B) She often eats in a French restaurant. (C) She usually takes a snack in the KFC.

input: M: We got the computer repaired last week. W: Oh, so it could be fixed.
target: What had the woman assumed? (A) They had received a broken computer. (B) She knew how to repair the computer. (C) The computer couldn't be fixed.

input: W: How many holidays do you have in the U.S.? M: Er, I'm not quite sure. I just know some. W: For example? M: Mmm..., Mother's Day, National Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year's Day, and Valentine's Day. W: Not bad. When does its National Day come? And the Valentine's Day? M: The National Day comes on July 4th and the latter on February 14th. W: Talking of the National Day, who is the Father of the state? Benjamin Franklin or George Washington? M: George Washington, of course. W: Besides Washington, who else is regarded as a great president? M: Abraham Lincoln, I'm one hundred per cent sure.
target: What were the two speakers talking about? (A) They were talking about the US holidays and so on. (B) They were talking about the US language and so on. (C) They were talking about the US presidents and so on.

input: W: Hi, Tom. It seems that you like sports very much. M: Hello, Jane. I just go to the gym for a workout once a week. When I was in college, I used to play basketball twice a week, and football every day.
target: How often did the man play basketball in college? (A) Every day (B) Once a week (C) Twice a week

input: W: Good morning. M: Good morning. I'm here to see Mr. Addison. W: Mr. Addison went to Washington on Monday afternoon for an exhibition, and won't be back until Thursday night. If you like, you can come again on Friday morning.
target: When will Mr. Addison return? (A) On Monday afternoon. (B) On Thursday night. (C) On Friday morning.

input: F: Would you mind if I turn the radio off? M: Not at all.
target: What will the woman do? (A) Do other things (B) Keep the radio on (C) Turn the radio off

input: W: I want to buy a sweater in that shop. M: I have been there before, and I don't think the styles suit you.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He has bought a sweater in that shop. (B) The sweaters are ugly. (C) She can't buy a suitable sweater in that shop.

input: M: We'd like two rooms, a small room and a large room both facing the garden. W: Very good, sir. The small room is twenty dollars a night, and the large room is thirty dollars a night.
target: How much would the man pay for the rooms if he and his family stay for three nights? (A) $36. (B) $40. (C) $150.

input: W: Oh, dear! M: I'm sorry. I do hope I haven't hurt you. W: Oh, no. I was just a little startled. That's all right. It's quite all right. M: But it isn't all right. I made you drop your shopping bags. Let me pick these bags up. W: You must have been in a great hurry. Never mind. M: I was only going to catch the bus. I'm afraid I wasn't looking where I was going. I hope nothing was destroyed. W: Oh, no. Thank you very much. M: I do apologize. W: Don't worry about it. There is no need to apologize. Look! Here comes the bus. You'll catch it if you run. M: Oh, so I shall.
target: Where does this conversation take place? (A) On a train. (B) Near a bus stop. (C) In a department store.

input: W: Would you like to go and see the new exhibit with us? M: That's the last thing in the world I ever want to do.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He definitely does not want to go. (B) He would like to go and see the exhibit. (C) He went to see the exhibit last year.

input: M: Have you heard about Tim? He had to be rushed to the emergency room. W: Really? I hope it's not too serious.
target: What can be inferred from the conversation? (A) Tim will get to the hospital quickly. (B) The woman's heard all about Tim's illness. (C) The woman doesn't know how Tim is now.

input: W: May I have a word with you? M: You've called me at a bad time. I'm writing a report and have to finish within an hour. W: You really like leaving things to the last minute. M: I know this is a terrible habit.
target: What do we know about the man? (A) He has been caught copying a report. (B) He is not free at the moment. (C) He won't leave till the last minute.

input: W: If it doesn't stop raining by Thursday, we'll have to cancel the fair. M: No, we could just hold it indoors in the gym. W: I've checked. The gym and the school-hall are both booked.
target: Why will the speakers have to cancel the fair? (A) Because it keeps raining. (B) Because the gym's being repaired. (C) Because the school-hall is full of books.

input: M: Do you know how old Dick is this year? W: Well, let me see. I'm 39 and he is 4 years younger.
target: How old is Dick now? (A) 39. (B) 43. (C) 35.

input: W: Mark was called up again to Mr. Allen's office. Apparently, he went against his class teacher again. M: They say he takes after his elder brother, Bobby. He used to get into a lot of trouble in school, too.
target: What can we know about Mark? (A) He causes much trouble at school. (B) He's Bobby's elder brother. (C) He and his brother look alike.

input: M: Mrs. Jones, you look very beautiful in the blue skirt, why not make one? W: Urn... just take a measure for me.
target: What is the woman going to do? (A) She is going to make a blue skirt. (B) She is not going to make a blue skirt. (C) She is not going to do anything.

input: W: Remember, Carl's birthday is June 2nd. M: Thanks for telling me. I thought it was sometime in July.
target: When is Carl's birthday? (A) July 2. (B) July 22. (C) June 2.

input: W: Take these pills three times a day. Two pills each time. M: Thank you.
target: Where does the woman work? (A) In a hospital (B) In a school (C) In a library

input: F: Are you a party member? M: I joined it two years ago.
target: How long has the man been a party member? (A) Two years. (B) One year. (C) Less than a year.

input: M: I am afraid Peter won't be back until 12:00. Shall I take a message for him? W: Oh, yeah, please ask him to give me a call when he gets back.
target: What does the woman want the man to do? (A) She wants the man to call her back. (B) She wants to leave a message for the man. (C) She wants the man to ask Peter to give her a ring.

input: M: The doctor told me to quit drinking coffee. F: Shouldn't you quit drinking tea, too?
target: What does the woman suggest? (A) Tea is better than coffee (B) The man should change to tea (C) The man shouldn't drink tea either

input: M: There is a movie tonight. Would you like to go and see it? W: I'm sorry. I have to prepare for tomorrow's test.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She has to see the movie. (B) She is tired. (C) She doesn't want to see the movie.

input: W: How on earth did that happen? Did you hit something? M: No. I was driving along when a stone suddenly hit the windscreen. W: How awful! What a good job it didn't hit you.
target: What happened to the man? (A) He fell on the ground. (B) His car's windscreen was broken. (C) He was hit by a stone.

input: W: How do you like the dishes in our restaurant? M: Oh, they are wonderful. It's quite some time since I have enjoyed myself so much. And your service is perfect, too.
target: What is the relationship between the speakers? (A) Teacher and student. (B) Doctor and patient. (C) Waitress and customer.

input: F: What's the date today? M: Four days later will be Teacher's Day.
target: Which of the following is right? (A) Today is Teacher's Day. (B) Tomorrow will be Teacher's Day. (C) Today is not Teacher's Day.

input: M: When did you first find the door broken and things missing? W: After I got up, around 5:20. Then I called the police station.
target: What are they talking about? (A) A traffic accident. (B) A fire. (C) A crime.

input: M: Professor Johnson seems so serious. W: But his lectures are quite humorous, aren't they?
target: What does the woman think about Professor Johnson? (A) He is very quiet. (B) He gives amusing lectures. (C) He should give more than one series of talks.

input: M: I'm really getting worried about Mary. She was sitting in for the exam in two weeks' time. But all she is talking about now is nothing but an upcoming concert. W: She may fail along that line. Let's try to talk some sense into her.
target: What are the speakers probably going to do? (A) To persuade Mary to spend more time on her lessons. (B) To help Mary to prepare for the upcoming concert. (C) To talk with Mary about going to the concert.

input: W: Sir, can I come in now? M: Sorry, Lady. I am afraid that you have to wait half an hour for our business hours that are from 8:30 am to 5:30 pm.
target: When did the man arrive? (A) 8:00. (B) 8:30. (C) 8:45.

input: W: Walter, it's not what I ordered. M: Oh, sorry.
target: Where are they talking? (A) In a restaurant. (B) In a police station. (C) In a post office.

input: W: Can I go out with friends, Dad? M: Yes, Carol, but you can't go out in those clothes. It's freezing today. W: Okay, Dad. I'll wear something warmer.
target: What does Carol's father ask her to do? (A) Talk with her friends. (B) Go out with him. (C) Put on warm clothes.

input: M: Excuse me. How can I get to the Prince Street? W: Take Bus No. 13 and get off at Prince Street stop. M: Can you tell me where I can buy such kind of shirt? W: Oh, that's easy. There's a man's shop just around the corner. M: Thank you.
target: Which bus should the man take to get to Prince Street? (A) Bus No. 12. (B) Bus No. 30. (C) Bus No. 13.

input: M: Mrs. Spencer, what time is Mr. Black's flight due to arrive at Boston Airport? W: Around 2:00 p.m., sir. Will you go with the company car to meet him? M: Yes. So I'd better leave here to no later than now. How about the hotel for Mr. Black and his party? W: I made the reservations for them last week and checked again yesterday to be sure everything is ready. M: Including the welcome room for tonight's reception? W: That's right. The manager promised me that everything would be exactly as we have requested. M: Excellent. I want everything to be the very best. W: I'm sure it will be. That manager has never let us down yet. M: We want to make a good impression. Not just to be sure that this business deal is a success, but to pay back the wonderful treatment we received from him in Tokyo last year.
target: When is the man leaving to pick up Mr. Black? (A) Around 2 p.m. (B) No later than 2 p.m. (C) Right after the conversation.

input: W: Jack, how are you doing with your paper? M: I've written and rewritten it so many times that I wonder when I can finish it.
target: What can we learn about the man? (A) He is modest. (B) He is satisfied. (C) He is upset.

input: M: I didn't work out this question. F: It is more difficult than the other two.
target: Why didn't the man work out the question? (A) He forgot it. (B) He is busy with other things. (C) It is more difficult.

input: W: Alex, did you stay in Seoul after you graduated from college? M: No, I was in Beijing for 5 years, but now I'm working in Guangzhou.
target: Where is Alex working now? (A) Seoul. (B) Guangzhou. (C) Beijing.

input: M: Do you like Chinese food? W: Yes, Ido. M: What's your favorite Chinese food? W: Mm. It's hard to say. I like hot and sour soup a lot but I guess I like bean curd better. M: Do you eat Chinese food often? W: Once in a while.
target: Dose the woman like Chinese food? (A) Yes. (B) No. (C) Unclear.

input: W: Do you have plans this weekend? M: Yes, it is my daughter's birthday. We will have a barbeque. W: Sweet, tell her happy birthday! I think my daughter will buy her a nice present.
target: What's the relationship between the speakers? (A) Friends. (B) Husband and wife. (C) Customer and salesgirl.

input: M: Do you know Joe Brown's number? W: No, but you can look it up in the telephone book.
target: How can the man find Mr. Brown's phone number? (A) By referring to the receptionist. (B) By finding it in the phone book. (C) By calling the telephone operator.

input: M: I'd like two tickets for the 10 o'clock train to Pittsburgh, please. W: One way, or round trip? M: One way, please. Oh, and one of them is for a child. W: Fine. That comes to 134.00.
target: is the man going to Pittsburgh? (A) By taxi. (B) By train. (C) By subway.

input: M: Does this bus go to the People's Park? F: No. I think you should take Bus No. 137.
target: Which bus go to the People's Park? (A) Bus No. 135. (B) Bus No. 137. (C) Bus No. 117.

input: W: What kind of music do you like best, classical, light or pop music? M: I really enjoy hip-hop, especially Jay Chou's. I think Jazz is boring.
target: What kind of music does the man like best? (A) Pop music. (B) Classical music. (C) Jazz.

input: M: Shall I send for a doctor? F: Don't bother. I'll be fine soon.
target: Will the doctor come? (A) No, he won't (B) Yes, he will come soon (C) We don't know

input: W: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please. M: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me. W: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today. M: Oh, why? Is she ill? W: No. She's studying for an exam. M: An exam. Is she going to school? W: Yes, she is. She's learning Japanese in night school. M: I see. Are you going to night school, too? W: No, I'm not, not this year. But I'm thinking about taking a course next year. M: That's a good idea. Is it expensive? W: No, not very. Anyway, it's worth the money.
target: Where are Kate and Tom? (A) In Kate's office. (B) In Tom's house. (C) In a classroom.

input: W: Do you want a day course or an evening course? M: Well, it will have to be an evening course since I work during the day.
target: What are they talking about? (A) The choice of course. (B) A day course. (C) An evening course.

input: W: Does this bus go to the Bank of China? M: Yes. Get off at the post office and walk straight ahead for about two minutes.
target: Where does the woman have to get off? (A) At the Bank of China. (B) At the post office. (C) At the next stop.

input: W: They really did a good job. M: Exactly. W: The singing group used to be very popular. M: I can't believe they could have played so well.
target: What are the speakers talking about? (A) A concert. (B) A singer. (C) A match.

input: W: How did you feel when you found out you had high blood pressure? M: Shocked! The problem for me was that there were no symptoms; it seemed to have sneaked up on me.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He is anxious to find a cure for his high blood pressure. (B) He doesn't think high blood pressure is a problem for him. (C) He was not aware of his illness until diagnosed with it.

input: W: Would you like a cup of tea? M: No, thanks. But I like some coffee, please.
target: What would the man like to have? (A) Tea. (B) Coffee. (C) Nothing.

input: W: Are you going to Canada or Mexico during your winter vacation? M: Well, I don't enjoy cold weather at all, and Canada is freezing in the winter time.
target: What can we learn about the man from the conversation? (A) He will probably wait until summer to go to Canada. (B) He will probably go to Mexico for his vacation. (C) He will probably go to Canada for his vacation.

input: W: How much are the flowers? W: Roses are 120 dollars, but the shopkeeper let me have it for 100 dollars.
target: What discount did the man get? (A) $20 off (B) $30 off (C) $40 off

input: W: What do you think of this newspaper? M: I think it has an excellent coverage of news ... both national and international. W: Why do you buy it? M: Well... the reason I choose it is that its reports are serious and it tells us the truth.
target: Why does the man buy the newspaper? (A) It's cheap. (B) It's excellent. (C) Its reports are true.

input: F: Hello, where are you going? M: To the cinema. Er...what about coming with me?
target: What Joes the man mean? (A) He will not go to the cinema himself. (B) He goes to the cinema very often. (C) He wants the woman to go with him.

input: M: Did you listen to the weather report this morning? W: Yes, I did. It will be cloudy in the afternoon. I hope that it won't rain. M: Have you made the sandwiches yet? W: No, I haven't. I'll start right away. Did you get the soft drinks? M: Yes, I did. They are in the refrigerator. W: Would you put plastic knives and forks in the picnic basket? And don't forget the paper plates and napkins. M: Oh, Nancy called a while ago. She told me that she would like to bring something for the picnic. W: I'll call her right away and ask her to bring a bottle of wine.
target: What are the speakers preparing for? (A) A picnic. (B) A travel abroad. (C) A birt hday party.

input: W: Am I standing in the right position? M: Uh ... just one thing, you should lift your feet a little higher, and keep your arms straight back. Now, when you go into the water, your head will go first and your legs will follow right along be-hind.
target: What sports are they talking about? (A) Skiing. (B) Basketball. (C) Diving.

input: M: Would you like to see a menu? W: No, thank you. I already know what I want to order.
target: What is the relationship between the two speakers? (A) Patient and doctor. (B) Wife and husband. (C) Waiter and customer.

input: W: What's the hurry? We'd like you to stay for dinner. M: Well, thank you, but Helen and I have to meet my parents at the railway station.
target: What will the man do next? (A) Leave right away. (B) Stay for dinner. (C) Catch a train.

input: W: Would you please lend me a hand with the box? M: All right.
target: What can we learn about the box from the dialogue? (A) It's heavy. (B) It's light. (C) It's empty.

input: F: Excuse me. Could you do me a favor? M: Yes, of course. What is it?
target: What does the woman want the man to do? (A) Tell her the name of the flower. (B) Help her with something. (C) Go to the cinema with her.

input: W: It's exciting just to think about it. It will be my first trip to Italy, but I may have trouble finding my way around when I'm there. M: Don't worry about that. Just give me a call when you arrive. I'll show you the way around.
target: What does the man offer to do for the woman? (A) He will go to the airport to meet the woman. (B) He will reserve a hotel room for the woman. (C) He will help her find her way around.

input: M: Excuse me, could you tell me the school bus schedule? W: Well, the bus leaves here for the campus every hour, starting at 6:30 a.m. But on Saturdays, the schedule starts half an hour later.
target: When does the first bus leave on Saturday? (A) At 6:30 a.m. (B) At 7:00 a.m. (C) At 7:30 a.m.

input: W: We are going to be late for the film! M: Take it easy, we still have time. W: What time does the film start? M: At 7:30. We have 45 minutes to get there.
target: What time is it now? (A) 6:30. (B) 6:15. (C) 6:45.

input: M: Is there anything we must do? W: Yes, if I were you, I would make a call to mum for we have to say goodbye to her before we leave.
target: What would the two speakers probably do first? (A) Give mum a call. (B) Visit mum. (C) Leave at once.

input: M: Hi, Melissa, how's your project going? Have you thought about going to graduate school? Perhaps you can get into Harvard. W: Everything is coming along really well. I have been thinking about graduate school. But I'll talk to my tutor Dr. Garcia first and see what she thinks.
target: What do you learn about the woman from the conversation? (A) She has been longing to attend Harvard University. (B) She'll consult Dr. Garcia about entering graduate school. (C) She has finished her project with Dr. Garcia's help.

input: M: I'd dike some red roses. W: Is it your wife's birthday? M: No, it's our wedding anniversary. She really likes roses. So I give her some every week. I just wish they would stay fresh longer than they do. W: If you put a little sugar in the water they will stay fresh for days. M: Really? I want to try to use white vinegar in the water and it helped a little. W: Sugar is even better. M: It is worth trying, I will tell my wife. How much do I owe you? W: Let's see. They are $ 10 a dozen. So that will be $ 5.00. M: OK. Here you are. W: Thank you. Here are the flowers.
target: How often does the man give his wife roses? (A) Every week. (B) Every month. (C) Every year.

input: W: Do you know what time the bread shop opens? M: It usually opens at half past six, but on Sunday it opens half an hour later.
target: What time does the bread shop open on Sunday? (A) At 6:00. (B) At 6:30. (C) At 7:00.

input: M: Oh, what a morning! You know I had so much work to do and the phone just kept ringing. Three sales people called me this morning. W: I know how it is. I get a lot of calls, too, even on weekends.
target: What are the two speakers doing? (A) Arguing. (B) Protesting. (C) Complaining.

input: W: Your boarding pass, please! M: Here it is. W: Thanks. M: Where is my seat? W: 15A. Just over there, sir. M: Thank you, Miss. By the way, where can I put my bag'? W: You can put your coat and small things on the shelf over your feet. M: I've got two bags. I'll afraid I can't put them down there. Can I put them on the shelf above? W: All right, sir. M: And where is the washroom? W: Behind the curtain. M: Thank you again. W: You're welcome.
target: What is the relationship between the two speakers? (A) Conductor and driver (B) Air hostess and passenger. (C) Waitress and customer.

input: W: Oh, no. It's five o'clock already, and I haven't finished my homework. M: Don't worry. That clock is fifteen minutes fast. You still have time to do it.
target: When does this conversation take place? (A) At 5:00. (B) At 5:15. (C) At 4:45.

input: M: It is snowing outside! It is unusual. F: Yes. I've never experienced such a cold winter.
target: What is true? (A) It is raining. (B) It is autumn. (C) It is cold winter.

input: M: Susan, have you read the notice on the bulletin board? I've won the scholarship for the next semester. W: I know you would. You certainly deserve it.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She has confidence in him. (B) She has also won a scholarship. (C) She is surprised at the news.

input: Jori: Hi Dave. [Hi] Happy to see you could make it. Come on in. Dave: Wow. Looks like the party is in full swing. Jori: Yeah. And they're eating me out of house and home. Oh, I'd like you to meet my sister, Carol. She's visiting for the weekend. Dave: Oh. Which one is she? Jori: She's sitting on the sofa over there. Dave: You mean the woman wearing the red sweater with the long black hair? Jori: Yeah. That's right. Let me introduce you to her. I just know you two will hit it off. You're both so outgoing and adventurous. Dave: Uh, and who's the man sitting next to her? Uh, the man with the suit jacket and flashy green tie? Jori: Oh, that's Bob, my karate teacher. Dave: Karate teacher! I never knew you were into karate. Jori: Yeah, I started about two months ago. Come on. I'd like you to meet them.
target: Who is visiting Jori for the weekend? (A) her best friend (B) her brother Bob (C) her sister

input: M: Congratulations, Betty. W: Thank you. What about Peter? M: Oh, he dropped the stick. W: Bad luck! Do you know who won the high jump? M: Joe from our class. W: Your class do very well at the sports meeting. By the way, what sport are you taking part in? M: Swimming. W: Good luck to you. M: Thank you.
target: Which sport did Peter probably take part in? (A) The relay race. (B) The high jump. (C) Ping-pong match.

input: M: Hi. You're back from Hong Kong. So how's it? W: It's very nice. The streets are clean and the food is good.
target: What are they talking about? (A) Streets. (B) Hong Kong. (C) Food.

input: M: How time flies! The winter holidays are coming next week. W: Yes, do you have any plans? M: Certainly. I want to go to Egypt. What about you? W: I'm afraid I can go nowhere. I failed my English exam. You know my parents are so strict with me. M: Bad luck! W: I see. Is Egypt an African country? Is it far? M: Yes, it's in Africa and quite far. But it's not only the Pyramids that I want to see but the Aswan Dam. W: You want to see? M: Of course. I'll go there by boat on the Nile. W: That'll be wonderful and interesting. How will you get there? M: By air - by flight No. CA808. My sister works on it. And then I'll be treated as a king! W: Don't be so proud. I'll be off now. I wish you a good trip. M: Oh, sorry. I didn't mean that. I don't want to hurt you...
target: What will the girl do during the winter? (A) She won't go anywhere for no money. (B) She will have to stay at home to study English. (C) She will be at Aswan Dam.

input: M: How much does one ticket cost? W: Two dollars for the general public, but children tickets are half price.
target: How much will the man pay for three children tickets? (A) $ 1. (B) $ 2. (C) $ 3.

input: M: Can you stay for supper? W: I'd like to, but I have to buy some meat and vegetables before my brother comes home from his office.
target: Where is the woman going now? (A) Her brother's office (B) Her own house. (C) The market.

input: W: National Bank, can I help you? M: Yes, please. What are your business hours? W: We open at 9:00 and close at 4:00 during the week, on Saturday we close one hour earlier at 3:00, and we are closed on Sunday.
target: When does the bank close on Saturday? (A) At l:00 pm. (B) At 3:00 pm. (C) At 4:00 pm.

input: M: Why, Mary Smith! I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been? W: John, John Brown! It has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year. M: No, we talked at the Johnsons' Christmas party last December. Don't you remember? W: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the food company? M: No, I changed jobs three months ago. I'm with the National Bank now. How about you? W: I'm still teaching at the university, but I moved from the German Department to the Spanish Department. Well,how is your family? Are the children all in school now? M: No, Billy is still at home. Tom is in the third grade and Jane's in the second. W: Our two children haven't started school yet, either. But they will go in the fall.
target: How long is it since they met each other? (A) More than one year. (B) Less than one year. (C) Three months.

input: W: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly? M: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house. W: Do you remember what time it happened? M: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch. W: Good. Now, was the truck going fast? M: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red. W: Are you sure, Mr. White? M: Yes, absolutely sure. W: Then the truck hit the taxi, did it? M: Yes, with much noise. Then I called the police. W: Well, thanks a lot, Mr. White. Good-bye. M: Good-bye.
target: What are the two speakers talking about? (A) A fight in the street. (B) A damaged house. (C) A traffic accident.

input: W: Hello. This is Barbara from the Rainbow Hotel. Is Jimmy at home? M: No. He's at the lab, but he will be back home at four o'clock.
target: Where is Jimmy now? (A) At a hotel. (B) At home. (C) At the lab.

input: W: When do you usually go to the bank, John? M: Anytime I have to. Why did you ask? W: You'd better avoid Friday mornings. I'm reading an interesting book these days. And it says most robberies happen on Friday mornings.
target: What is the woman's purpose in speaking to the man? (A) To tell him about a bank robbery. (B) To recommend a good book to him. (C) To give him some advice on safety.

input: M: I have passed the test. W: Congratulations.
target: Why is the man so happy? (A) He failed the test. (B) He passed the test. (C) He didn't have the test.

input: M: Good morning, Miss Smith. I'm sorry to trouble you. W: Good morning, not at all. Please be seated. What can I do for you? M: It's about my son. W: He isn't in trouble. I hope he's doing well in all his lessons. He'll do well in the exams. M: Except in Chinese. I'm afraid. He says that he is a little weak in Chinese. W: Is he? I'm sorry to hear that. M: That's why I've come to see you. I'm worried about his Chinese. He may fall behind the others when he comes back. W: What do you mean? M: We'll go back to London for a holiday for two months. We haven't been back for three years. W: I see. I think that maybe his Chinese teacher can give him some homework to do during the holiday. He won't fall too far behind the others when he comes back.
target: Why does the man go to see the woman? (A) Because he will go back to England. (B) Because his son will go back to England. (C) Because he is concerned about his son's studies.

input: W: But why so early? You don't have to be at work until eight. M: After six the bus gets crowded, I wouldn't get a seat.
target: What do we know about the man? (A) He drives to work at 6. (B) He is a bus driver. (C) He begins to work at 8.

input: W: Mr. Wilson, you said you saw the bus crash into the truck. Do you know what caused the accident? M: I saw a boy riding his bicycle in the street. The bus driver tried to avoid biting him. He made a sudden turn and lost control the bus.
target: What caused the bus driver to loss control of the bus? (A) He made a sudden turn. (B) He drove the bus over a bicycle. (C) He tried to avoid hitting the truck.

input: W: Which impresses you more, a book or a movie? M: The latter one would be my favorite. A great many movies have impressed me. But the first time what I watched was Titanic. In my memory, I first watched Titanic when I was a pupil in the second grade, though I didn't know too much about the love between men and women. I was terribly shocked by the horrible catastrophe when it is sinking. Some are screaming, some are too scared to say a word, some are murmuring prayers in the Bible and begging for the God's mercy. All in all, that was the first time I had viewed people's psychological status when confronted with the great disaster. And I learnt that men, including me, should always show respect to nature or properly reduce our confidence when saying men can conquer the world.
target: What choice will the man make between a book and a movie? (A) Both a book and a movie. (B) Not a book but a movie. (C) Either a book or a movie.

input: M: Who knows the answer to the problem on the board? Anyone? Yes, Melanie? W: Mr. Brooks, can I have a bathroom pass? I really have to go. M: Melanie, you're supposed to take care of these things before class starts. Can't you read the sign on the wall? W: I know, Mr. Brooks. M: I'll tell you what, Melanie. If you give me the correct answer, I'll let you go. W: Fine...the correct answer is 34, I think. M: OK. Just please be back as soon as you can.
target: Which subject does Mr. Brooks teach probably? (A) English. (B) Art. (C) Math.

input: W: My father is going to retire soon. M: Is he? Why? W: He is not in good health now. M: I am sorry to hear that.
target: Why is the woman's father going to retire? (A) He is old. (B) He is in good health. (C) He is in poor health.

input: M: Are you moving into a new house? Need a hand with those boxes? W: That's okay, I can manage. They look big, but aren't very heavy actually.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) She thinks the man should have helped earlier. (B) She doesn't need the man's help. (C) She doesn't know the boxes are heavy.

input: W: Are you coming with us to Hilda's birthday party? M: I'd love to, but I have an appointment with my dentist.
target: What do we learn about the man? (A) He is ill. (B) He will go to the party. (C) He will see a doctor.

input: M: What a beautiful bike! When did you buy it? W: I didn't know. It was a birthday present from my aunt.
