target: Who bought the bike for her? (A) Her uncle. (B) Her father. (C) Her aunt.

input: M: Why is Susan looking upset? W: I had her play piano instead of going out to play.
target: Why is Susan looking unhappy? (A) Because her mother blamed her for not playing piano. (B) Because she was not allowed to play piano. (C) Because she had to play piano instead of going out to play.

input: M: How long will we stay at the cam? W: We'll stay there for one night. That is, we will leave the camp on August 7th.
target: When will the speakers arrive at the camp? (A) On August 5th. (B) On August 6th. (C) On August 7th.

input: W: That was such an interesting movie! I hope you enjoy it as much as I did. M: I must admit that I fell asleep after the first thirty minutes.
target: How does the woman feel about the movie? (A) Boring. (B) Interesting. (C) Annoying.

input: M: Now if you have any questions about the contract. I'll be happy to answer them. W: Nothing comes to mind right now, but I'd like to go over all the articles of the contract once more before signing it.
target: What are the speakers doing right now? (A) Drawing up a business plan. (B) Discussing a term paper. (C) Finalizing a contract.

input: W: John, the American film "Titanic" will be on next Tuesday. M: When?
target: What does John want to know about the film? (A) The name of the film. (B) When the film will be on. (C) Where the film will be on.

input: W: John. would you like swimming with me? M: I'd love to, but I have to go home. I have to help my mother to do the housework.
target: What will John do? (A) He'd like to go swimming with the girl. (B) He'd like to go home and watch TV. (C) He is going to go home to help his mother with the housework.

input: M: Kate, why does the downtown area look deserted now? W: Well, there used to be some really good stores, but lots of them moved out to the mall.
target: What do we learn from the conversation? (A) There isn't much business downtown nowadays. (B) Shoppers can only find good stores in the mall. (C) Lots of people moved out of the downtown area.

input: W: How would you introduce volleyball? M: I was once a high school man teacher and basketball coach. I never played volleyball before and I've seen it just once in my life. One day my school needed a lot of coaches for our girls' team. I was one of the youngest teachers on stuff and the girls talked me helping coach volleyball. The girls they have were great and they began to start. A friend of mine was a volleyball player. He taught me beginning and then taught me how to coach it. W: What sports did you play in high school? M: I played basketball, tennis and golf. I was not a volleyball player at all. I was pretty good at basketball. But then my real passion was gone. I played it every day. W: When did you know you want to be a full-time volleyball coach? M: It wouldn't take very long. I've been coaching women's basketball that I really love it. But when I saw an opportunity in women's volleyball, because coaches were needed. In this way, I become a college coach immediately. I like coaching women's volleyball at college very much because it seems to fit my personality.
target: Who persuaded the man into coaching volleyball? (A) His boss. (B) His school. (C) His friends.

input: Boy: Mum, have we got any fruit to take on the picnic? I thought there were some oranges and bananas. Mother: Here are the bananas. Let's take them. Oh the oranges have all gone. What about taking some grapes or apples as well? Boy: OK, let's take the grapes. That'll be enough.
target: What fruit will they take? (A) Grapes and oranges. (B) Grapes and apples. (C) Bananas and grapes.

input: W: I understand how you feel, sir. But there simply isn't any room. The person who received your reservation call must have forgotten to write it down. I'm afraid it was just a mistake. She is new, you know. M: Just a mistake? Do you realize that I've invited some very important people to dinner? It could cause me to lose an important business partner. W: I'm sorry, sir. I suggest you call them and explain the problem. I'm sure you'll find several other very good restaurants around here. M: I can't get in touch with them now. They are probably on their way at this very minute. Surely you could fit one more table in. W: Not unless you'd like me to put you in the hall, sir. M: Well, that's better than nothing.
target: Why is the man annoyed? (A) The woman treats him coldly. (B) His reservation was overlooked. (C) He lost a business partner.

input: M: Are you doing anything exciting this summer, Sandy? W: We are, as a matter of fact. Nick's boss says we can have the beach house in Florida for two weeks. M: That's great!
target: Where does the woman probably go for her holiday? (A) The countryside. (B) A forest. (C) A beach.

input: M: Are you going to visit Uncle Wang's factory next week? W: No, we're going to the West Hill Farm.
target: What are they going to do next week? (A) Going to visit West Hill. (B) Going to visit the West Hill Farm. (C) Going to visit uncle Wang's factory.

input: W: We are going to change our meeting from Monday to Tuesday. M: It's all the same to me.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He can't attend the two-day meeting. (B) He can't attend the meeting on Monday. (C) He can attend the meeting on either day.

input: M: I think something is wrong with Mr. Hudson. He's not as cheerful as usual. W: I don't know what it could be. M: I heard last week that his mother had been ill. I wonder if that's the trouble. W: I doubt that. Yesterday he told me his mother felt much better. M: Maybe he has a problem here at work. W: I don't think that he has any problems with his job. It's well-known that Mr. Hudson is the best worker among us. M: Perhaps there is some trouble in his home. W: Well. The headmaster phoned this morning. M: That must be the problem. He's worried about his son.
target: What's the matter with Hudson's mother? (A) She was ill,but she felt much better. (B) She was seriously ill. (C) She went to see him.

input: M: I think I'll give Jack a call now. W: Isn't it a little late at night?
target: What does the woman imply? (A) She asked the man to call Jack late at night. (B) Jack gets home late in the evening. (C) It would be better to call another time.

input: M: I'm terribly sorry, Anna, I lost the magazine you lent me the other day. W: It doesn't matter. It was a back number any way.
target: Why doesn't the woman care about the lost magazine? (A) It is no longer of any use to her. (B) It doesn't have a back cover. (C) She feels the man's apology is enough.

input: W: I expected you'd come to my birthday party yesterday. M: I'm terribly sorry. Susan. I had to see off a friend of mine at the airport last night.
target: What did the man do last night? (A) He went to visit a friend. (B) He went to say goodbye to his friend at the airport. (C) He went to another city with his friend.

input: M: That is $ 3.50 on the meter, and a dollar extra for the suitcase. W: OK. Here is five dollars. Keep the change.
target: How much was the driver's tip? (A) $3.5. (B) $0.5. (C) $1.5.

input: W: Why did you sell the car? M: It was giving me too much trouble. I was spending so much money on it that I was... er... spending more money than it was worth. Unfortunately, of course. When you actually sell the car, you've already spent the money on it, so you lose both ways. W: What was wrong with your old car? M: The engine needs many repairs and the wheels were giving trouble now and then, when I set off on a journey, it gave me a sort of fear that I might not reach the other end. So I decided to change it. W: Is the new car good? M: Yes, It's newer, more comfortable, and it hasn't given me any trouble at all. When I set off, I'm quite sure that I'll be able to get to the other end safely.
target: What did the man do about his old car? (A) He sold it. (B) He repaired the engine. (C) He gave it to his friend as a present.

input: M: Good morning, Professor Li. I am Tom Green. Now I am working for the health magazine. Do you mind spending some time with me on the issue of AIDS? W: Not at all. Go ahead, please.
target: What is the Tom Green? (A) An author. (B) A reporter. (C) A teacher.

input: M: I'm sorry I have to ask you these questions, ma'am, but we want to catch the person who shot your husband. W: It was about 2 a.m. We had been sleeping for a couple of hours when we heard a noise downstairs.
target: What's the man's occupation? (A) He is a policeman. (B) He is a doctor. (C) He is a teacher.

input: W: If you had listened to me, we'd be at the party, Marty. More over, I'll drive. M: I was sure I knew the way there. I'll turn around.
target: What's the problem? (A) The man can't drive. (B) The party is over. (C) They are lost.

input: F: Is it raining outside? M: No. The rain has stopped. It's cloudy now.
target: What's the weather like? (A) It's raining. (B) It's cloudy. (C) The rain hasn't stopped.

input: M: Where are you from? W: The United States. I live in New York. M: Oh, really? That's a big city with a large population, right? By the way, do you like it there? W: Yeah. I think it's the only suitable place to live. M: Why do you say that? W: You see, there's always something exciting to do, and it's never boring. M: My place isn't boring, either. You can fish, hike, grow vegetables, and do all kinds of things, although it's small and quiet. W: It sounds like you really like it here in New Zealand.
target: Why does the woman think that New York is the only suitable place to live? (A) She can meet people from all over the world. (B) It offers a colorful and exciting life. (C) It's not only interesting but also quiet.

input: M: Do you mind if I open the window? W: Not a bad idea,we need some fresh air.
target: What do you learn about the woman? (A) She wants to keep the window tidy. (B) She doesn't like the man's idea. (C) She agrees with the man.

input: W: Could you please explain the homework for Monday again, Mr. Tang? M: Certainly. Read the next chapter and prepare to discuss what you've read.
target: What is the relationship between the two speakers? (A) Student and teacher. (B) Patient and nurse. (C) Wife and husband.

input: M: How time flies! The summer holidays are coming next week. W: Yes, do you have any plan? M: Certainly. I want to go to Egypt. What about you? W: I'm afraid I can't go anywhere. I failed my English written exam. You know my parents are so strict with me. M: Bad luck! W: I say, is Egypt an Asian country? Is it far? M: Yes, quite far. But it's not in Asia, it's an African country. W: Oh, yes. I've heard of not only the Pyramids but also the Aswan Dam. Do you want to see them? M: Of course. I'll go there by boat on the Nile. W: That'll be wonderful and interesting. How will you go to Egypt? M: By air---by flight No. CA 808! My sister works on it! And then I'll be treated as a king! W: Don't be so proud. I'll be off now. I wish you a good trip. M: Oh, sorry. I didn't mean to hurt you.
target: What will the girl do in summer holidays? (A) Study English at home. (B) Go boating on the Nile. (C) Visit the Aswan Dam.

input: W: Is there anything you can do to make the cold go away more quickly? M: No, there isn't. And a cold isn't really serious enough for a visit to a doctor.
target: What can we learn from the conversation? (A) Cold is a kind of serious illness. (B) Cold will go away quickly. (C) You needn't do anything about it.

input: W: Hey, Bob, what are you up to this weekend? M: Nothing in particular. Why? Do you have something in mind? W: Yeah. A friend of mine told me about a relatively new bar in the centre of town. It's called The Pharmacy and the decor is made of old medical stuff.
target: What are they talking about? (A) A new bar in the town. (B) A friend of the woman's. (C) The plan for the weekend.

input: M: Jenny, could you prepare the report for tomorrow's meeting? W: OK. I'll do it right away.
target: What's the possible relationship between the two speakers? (A) Husband and wife. (B) Waiter and customer. (C) Boss and employee.

input: F: What a cold day today! M: It is really colder than before.
target: What is the weather like before? (A) Colder. (B) Warmer. (C) As cold as now.

input: M: Good morning, Laura, what do you want to talk to me about? W: Good morning, professor Smith. I want to talk to you about changing my major. You see, I've decided to work in art museum when I graduate in three years, I think I should change my major to art history. M: You know, Laura, I think you should give this decision after some more thought. You've do well in your years of business major, the sign is, all organizations need good managers. W: That's true, but wasn't I still have to know a lot about art? M: Why not attend a few lectures in art history and try working a few hours a week as a volunteer at the local art museum to see if you really like working there.
target: What is the probable relationship between the two speakers? (A) Manager and job applicant. (B) Teacher and student. (C) Professor and teaching assistant.

input: M: Look what's on tomorrow, mother. That's the program you like about animals. It's before dinner. Let's watch it together. W: OK. You want to watch the space film at 7 o'clock, don't you? M: No, we can't. We're going to grandma's after dinner. W: Oh, yes, that's right.
target: What will the speakers do tomorrow evening? (A) Visit their Grandma (B) Watch a space film on TV (C) Watch a program about animals

input: M: Excuse me, Madam. My fight is BA6520. Is this my gate? W: That's right. Please show your ticket and ID card.
target: What is the man doing now? (A) Checking in. (B) Paying money. (C) Buying tickets.

input: M: The assignment on physics is a real challenge. I don't think I can finish it on time or by myself. W: Why don't we join our feet together? It may be easier then.
target: What does the woman suggest? (A) They join the physics club. (B) They ask for an extension of the deadline. (C) They work on the assignment together.

input: M: Have you been here before, Lucy? W: Yes, this is the third time that I've been in Yantai.
target: How many times has Lucy been in Yantai? (A) 3 times. (B) 4 times. (C) 5 times.

input: W: We are going to visit the Summer Palace tomorrow. M: Are you? May I join you.'?
target: What does the man mean? (A) He wants to go with them. (B) He will invite his friends. (C) He is not interested in going.

input: M: I have a high fever and I think I'm going to die. W: Well, let me examine you first. How long have you been like this? M: A week. Is it serious? W: Nothing serious. Take some medicine and you will get well soon.
target: How is the man now? (A) He is sound and safe. (B) He is going to die. (C) He doesn't feel well.

input: W: Judy earned a lot of money over the summer as a consultant for that agency. M: I don't doubt it. What surprises me is that she is still working there, now that classes have started again.
target: What does the man say about Judy? (A) He's surprised she chose that agency. (B) He wonders why she's still kept her job. (C) He doesn't know when her classes started.

input: M: Good morning, madam. Come in. What can I do for you? W: Well. I'm having difficulty in sleeping. I often wake up at three in the morning and I just can't get back to sleep.
target: What's the relationship between the speakers? (A) Neighbors. (B) Boss and employee. (C) Doctor and patient.

input: M: Excuse me; may I have a look at that book? W: Sure, but if you want to take it, you have to pay in cash.
target: Where does this conversation probably take place? (A) In the library. (B) In a bookstore. (C) In an office.

input: M: Would you like to have a copy of Dr Smith's article? W: Thanks, if it's not too much trouble.
target: What does the woman imply? (A) She doesn't want to take the trouble to read the article. (B) She would like to have a copy of the article. (C) She has given the man much trouble.

input: W: I have so much to do. M: Take it easy, school doesn't start until next week.
target: What does the man mean? (A) School begins later this year. (B) He wants her to relax. (C) She'd start her work early.

input: M: I paid 45 dollars for this pair of pants. W: Look at mine. They were twelve dollars cheaper than yours.
target: How much did the woman's pants cost? (A) $45 (B) $33 (C) $ 12

input: W: I want a ticket to London, please. Second class. M: Single or return?
target: What is the man? (A) A ticket seller. (B) A passenger. (C) A writer.

input: W: Jack,I can't find Volumn Ten. Could you check for me who borrowed it? M: Here it is, on the upper shelf, next to Volumn Two.
target: Why can't the woman find the book? (A) It is difficult to identify. (B) It has been misplaced. (C) It is missing.

input: W: Have you got any idea what you'll buy for Mary's birthday? M: Well, I'll buy her a school bag. And I promised to take her to a film. What about you? W: Oh, I haven't decided yet. I probably buy her a new music record.
target: What gift will the woman probably get for Mary? (A) A school bag (B) A record (C) A theater ticket

input: W: Dr. Block, I need to take a few days off because my father is coming over to visit. And I need to show him around the city. M: Ok, Jane. But be sure tocome back to work next week.
target: What is Jane doing? (A) Planning a tour. (B) Calling her father. (C) Asking for leave.

input: W: Will you go to America alone? M: My mother will go with me.
target: Who will go to America? (A) The woman. (B) The man. (C) The man and his mother.

input: W: I've noticed that you spend a lot of time tending your garden. Would you like to join our gardening club? We meet every other Wednesday. M: Oh, thanks for the invitation, but this is how I relax. I'd rather not make it something formal and structured.
target: What can we infer about the man? (A) He declines to join the gardening club. (B) He is a professional gardener in town. (C) He prefers to keep his gardening skills to himself.

input: W: What can I bring you, sir? M: I want a big burger and a cup of tea. W: Just a moment, sir.
target: Where is the man? (A) In a restaurant. (B) In a hotel. (C) In a hospital.

input: M: Our flight will be delayed by 6 hours. That means it won't be leaving until 3:30 in the afternoon. W: What shall we do in the meantime? M: Let's find some seats in the quiet part of the terminal to take a nap. W: Good idea. I am pretty tired.
target: What are the speakers going to do? (A) Change to another flight. (B) Take a rest while waiting. (C) Take their seats on the flight.

input: M: Excuse me, I'm a reporter from China Daily. I'd like to know what types of newspaper people often read. Would you mind answering a few questions? W: No, not at all. M: Can you tell me where you're from, please? W: Er, I was born in Japan and grew up in Italy. M: Oh, sounds interesting. Are you used to living here, in New York city? W: Very much so. I've been working in a college for three years. M: Woo, a college teacher. And when do you normally read newspapers? W: Well, I'm busy during the day, so usually after 8:00 o'clock at night. M: What sections do you prefer? W: I'm mainly interested in the shopping. Other than that, I also like the news.
target: Where does the woman work? (A) In Italy. (B) In Japan. (C) In America.

input: W: If I were you, I'd be more careful about locking the back door at night. M: Don't worry. No one will break in.
target: What does the woman worry about? (A) The man will not be able to sleep. (B) Someone will enter the back door while the man is sleeping. (C) The lock on the door will break.

input: W: I got 90 in my math exam. M: I got 9 5,but Linda was the best in my class. She got 98.
target: What was the mark the woman got in her exam? (A) 90. (B) 95. (C) 98.

input: W: I saw Andes at the hospital this morning. I wonder if his mother is ill again. M: No. She is fine. W: Then was he visiting someone there? M: No. He was there just to have a medical examination.
target: Why was Andes at the hospital? (A) To take a medical test. (B) To care for his mother (C) To pay a visit to his friend.

input: W: So what did you buy? M: A T-shit, it was a real bargain. I got it half price, saving 15 dollars.
target: What was the normal price of the T-shirt? (A) $15. (B) $30. (C) $50.

input: W: I'm Sue from Daily Magazine. We're doing a study of transport service in this area. Can you answer some questions? M: How long will it take? I'm in a hurry. W: It takes only a few minutes. M: Yes. OK. W: Do you live near the place of your work? M: Oh, no, I don't. W: Do you live one to five kilometers from your job, or six to ten, or more than ten kilometers? M: More than ten. Fourteen or fifteen. W: And, how do you go to work? M: By train. W: Do your family members always use public transport? M: Yes, they go to work or school by bus. W: Thank you very much, sir. M: You are welcome.
target: What is the woman doing? (A) She is doing an experiment. (B) She is having a study. (C) She is asking others for help.

input: M: Some more soup, please? W: Oh, yes. Just a little.
target: How much soup does the woman want? (A) Much. (B) Little. (C) A little.

input: W: How long have you been in this company? M: I have been here for about 8 years. I came here when I was twenty-one.
target: How old is the man now? (A) 22 years old. (B) 28 years old. (C) 29 years old.

input: W: John, I thought you were going to leave early today to take your son to the show. M: I'm still planning to. But I can't leave until I finish typing all the letters. W: Can you leave that until tomorrow? M: No. The boss wants them first thing tomorrow morning. W: How many have you got left? M: About five. W: Why don't you just go ahead, John? I'll do the letters for you. M: Thank you very much, Janet. You're so kind.
target: Where are the speakers? (A) In a classroom. (B) In a theatre. (C) In an office.

input: M: Finally, I've got the chance to put on my new suit tonight. I hope to make a good impression on your family. W: Come on! It's only a family reunion. So jeans and T-shirts are just fine.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The man has left a good impression on her family. (B) The man can dress casually for the occasion. (C) The man should buy himself a new suit.

input: M: Do you think we have made enough food for the party? W: The refrigerator is about to explode.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) There is a bomb in the refrigerator. (B) They will probably run out of food. (C) More than enough food has been prepared.

input: M: Your son seems to have made much progress in playing the piano. Does he attend any piano classes? W: Yes, he takes lessons twice a week, but from next week on, he will go to the class on Saturday evenings too.
target: How often will the woman's son have piano lesson from next week on? (A) Once a week. (B) Twice a week. (C) Three times a week.

input: M: What are you going to do this summer vacation? W: I want to have a trip to Beijing because I have never been there. But my mother wants me to stay at home and study since I am going to take the National Entrance Examination next year.
target: Which of the following can we know from the dialogue? (A) The woman is going to have a trip this summer vacation. (B) The woman is going to stay at home this summer vacation. (C) The woman hasn't decided how to spend the summer vacation.

input: F: Would it be convenient to see you today? M: Yes. My office hours are from 10 to 18.
target: When could the woman visit the man? (A) 10:00~18:00 (B) 6:00~10:00 (C) 10:00~8:00

input: M: Are you ready yet? W: I'll be ready in a couple of minutes. M: Hurry, please! We have to be at the hotel in fifteen minutes. W: Do I have to make a speech tonight? M: Just a short one, after dinner. W: What about television? Will they have cameras there? M: I certainly hope so. I'd like to see you on every news program in town tonight. W: I'll be glad when the voting is over. I'd like to have a good night's sleep more than anything else right now. I have to shake hands with so many people.
target: Where will the woman's speech be on? (A) On the radio. (B) On TV. (C) On the telephone

input: M: Why don't I take out the garbage? W: Please do. I haven't got time to do it yet.
target: What will the man probably do? (A) Eat cabbage. (B) Put the car in the garage. (C) Throw out the rubbish.

input: M: Mum, I can't find my socks for basketball. Have you seen them? W: Let me see. Are they white? M: Yes. Where did you see them? W: I saw them in the sitting-room just now. You may go and get them. M: Oh. Here they are! W: You should put your things away. M: OK. I will.
target: What is the man looking for? (A) His basketball. (B) His socks. (C) His shoes for basketball.

input: M: I hear you drive a long way to work every day. W: Oh, yes. It's about sixty miles. But it doesn't seem that far, the road is not bad, and there's not much traffic.
target: How does the woman feel about driving to work? (A) She is tired of driving in heavy traffic. (B) She doesn't mind it as the road conditions are good. (C) She is unhappy to have to drive such along way every day.

input: W: If that man gives me any more letters to type, I'll scream. He's given me ten already today, and there'll be more when I get back from coffee break. I'll be here till midnight. M: Calm down, Franny. He can't make you stay after five. Finish what you can, and leave the rest for Mary. W: But they're important letters, Joe. They should go out tonight. M: That's not your worry. If they're important, he should have given them to you earlier.
target: Who is the woman complaining about? (A) Her boss. (B) Her husband. (C) Her friend.

input: W: Your room is a mess. When is the last time you tidied your room? M: It was when Linda came over. She is been so helpful that I simply can't do without her.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He hasn't cleaned his room since Linda visited him. (B) Linda is the only person who ever comes to see him. (C) He's been too busy to clean his room.

input: M: Maybe I ought to subscribe to the Engineering Quarterly. It contains a lot of useful information. W: Why not read it in the library and save some money?
target: What is the woman's advice to the man? (A) To find a better science journal in the library. (B) Not to subscribe to the journal. (C) To buy the latest issue of the magazine.

input: M: I didn't finish my English homework last week. W: I didn't either. And the English teacher was very angry with me.
target: Who are talking? (A) Two students. (B) Two policemen. (C) Two tourists.

input: F: Did you enjoy yourself at the dancing party last night? M: Yes, I enjoyed it very much.
target: Where was the man last night? (A) In the park. (B) At the dance. (C) At home.

input: M: Have you found the trouble with the car? W: Not yet. The engine works well. I'm checking over the wheels.
target: What are the two speakers talking about? (A) Fixing an engine. (B) Repairing a car. (C) Cashing a check.

input: M: Joe just went down to the engineering meeting. W: Where is it?
target: What does the woman want to know? (A) Where the meeting is being held. (B) Where Joe will meet her. (C) What the topic of the meeting is.

input: M: I know I promise to drive you to the airport next Thursday, but I'm afraid something has come up. They've called a special meeting at work. W: No big deal. Karen said she was available as a back-up.
target: What does the woman mean? (A) The man should keep his words. (B) She regrets asking the man for help. (C) Karen can take her to the airport.

input: W1: Yes, ma'am. Can I help you? W2: Yes, I'd like to exchange this sweater. W1: What seems to be the matter? W2: Well, you see, I got this as a birthday present, but it's the wrong size. W1: Do you have the receipt? W2: Yes. W1: Could I see it, please? W2: Well, here you are. W1: What size do you want? W2: Just one size larger.
target: What does the buyer want to do? (A) To buy a sweater. (B) To exchange a sweater. (C) To hold a birthday party.

input: M: Mum,I feel like going out for a walk. W: Go ahead, please. But remember to be back before nine.
target: What would the boy like to do? (A) He is going out to work. (B) He wants to go for a walk. (C) He would like to find a job.

input: W: Do you think he could help me change the water in the fish tank this week? M: I don't know. He's pretty busy.
target: What does the woman need? (A) Someone to change the fish tank. (B) Someone to water the garden. (C) Someone to change the water.

input: M: Have you read this book, Helen? W: No, what is it about? M: It's about the differences between man and woman. I wouldn't say it a scientific book, but it causes me laughing all the way through.
target: How does the man think of the book? (A) Humorous. (B) Scientific. (C) Popular.

input: M: Are you buying that book on ships? I didn't know you were interested in ships. W: I'm not. I've just been looking at the pictures. No, this is the one I'm buying-on modern aircraft. M: I thought you hated flying. W: I do, but I love watching planes.
target: What is the woman going to buy? (A) A book on planes. (B) Pictures of ships. (C) A book on ships.

input: M: Hello, Ms Thomas. What can I do for you? W: Well, I've been having bad stomach pains lately, doctor. M: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. How long have you been having them? W: Just in the last few weeks. I get a very sharp pain about an hour after having meals. M: I see. Do you get this after every meal? W: Let me think. No, it's usually in the afternoon, after lunch. M: Well, what do you have for lunch? W: Oh, I mostly just have a quick hamburger and rush back to the office. We're very busy at the moment. M: Well, I don't think it's a serious thing. Maybe you eat too quickly. It's bad for your health. W: My husband is always telling me that. M: Anyway, I'll give you something for it and see what happens. Take the medicine three times a day. W: After meals or before? M: After eating. W: Thank you, doctor. M: You're welcome.
target: Where does this conversation take place? (A) In a restaurant. (B) In a hospital. (C) At the office.

input: W: That lecture was really wonderful. M: I couldn't agree with you more.
target: What does the man mean? (A) He disagrees with the woman. (B) He shares the woman's opinion. (C) He wasn't able to hear the lecture.

input: W: The shirt is fifty dollars, but I only have fifteen. M: I can lend you the rest, Kate.
target: How much money will he lend to Kate? (A) Fifteen dollars. (B) Fifty dollars. (C) Thirty-five dollars.

input: W: professor White's presentation seemed to go on forever. I was barely able tostay awake. M: How could you sleep through it? It's one of the best that I've heard on this topic.
target: What does the man think of professor white's presentation? (A) He finds the presentation hard to follow. (B) He considers the presentation verydull. (C) He speaks highly of the presentation.

input: W: Mary seems to think that the price will be going up again. M: That's her opinion, most others think differently. W: But sometimes she seems to have a good judgement. M: Oh, really?
target: What does the man mean? (A) Mary is practically the only one who thinks so. (B) Most people will go downtown. (C) Few people will be surprised at the price.

input: W: What's the matter? Are you hurt? M: I slipped on the stairs and fell down. I think my arm is broken. W: Let me see. I don't think it's broken, but we are going to see the doctor right now.
target: What has happened to the man? (A) He's broken his arm. (B) He's hurt his arm. (C) He's hurt himself.

input: M: Hi, Sue. How's it going? W: Oh, hi, Frank, just fine. How are your classes? M: Pretty good. I'm glad this is my last term here, though. W: Why is that? I thought you were enjoying school. M: I was. But now I'm getting tired of it. I'm ready for the real world. W: What are you planning to do when you graduate? M: First, I want to get a job as a computer programmer, and then after five years or so, I'd like to start my own business. W: Sounds good. I still have three terms to go until I'm done. M: You'll make it for sure. Well, see you later. W: Bye!
target: What is the probable relationship between the speakers? (A) Schoolmates. (B) Colleagues. (C) Roommates.

input: M: If you really have important things to go out you'd better take an umbrella. W: Thank you? I've got the weather forecast.
target: What is the weather going to be? (A) Sunny. (B) Windy. (C) Rainy.

input: W: You are interested in sports, aren't you? M: Yes. I go swimming once a week and play tennis twice a month.
target: How often does the man go swimming? (A) Once a week. (B) Twice a week. (C) Once a month.

input: W: You wanted to see me, Mr. Wright? M: Yes, Miss Gray. You'll have to start getting to work on time, or your service will no longer be needed here.
target: What happened to Miss Gray? (A) She was given a new job. (B) She was given a raise. (C) She was criticized for being late.

input: M: I kept looking for Mary at the seminar but never did see her. I can't imagine she forgot about it. She's been talking about it for weeks. W: Oh she didn't. It's just that she caught a really bad cold a couple of days ago.
target: What can be inferred from the conversation? (A) Mary hadn't planned to attend the seminar. (B) Mary has been ill for several weeks. (C) Mary wasn't able to attend the seminar.

input: W: You Americans are funny. It seems as if you were married with cars. M: Yeah, I guess that's true. The country is becoming one big highway. I was reading that there are about 4 million miles of roads and highways in this country now.
target: What are they talking about? (A) Families with cars. (B) American's heavy dependence on cars. (C) Roads and highways.

input: W: Next? M: Can I have a pound of chicken and two pounds of pork, please? W: Do you want a whole chicken, chicken wings, or some pieces without any bones in them? M: The last one. W: OK. That's $4 a pound, and the pork is going to be $6 in total. Anything else? M: No, that's it. Can I give you a credit card? W: I'm sorry, but the credit card machine is down. So it'll have to be cash or a personal check. M: Good thing. I stopped at an ATM machine on my way over here!
target: How much does the pork cost? (A) $3 per pound. (B) $4 per pound. (C) $6 per pound.

input: M: It's rather cold. Do you mind if I turn on the heater? F: Oh, no, not at all.
target: Can the man turn on the heater? (A) Yes, he can (B) No, he can't (C) We don't know

input: W: Is this the right place to sign up for the Spanish class? M: No, this room is for German. The Spanish class is held down the hall, right next to the French one.
target: Which language does the woman want to study? (A) German. (B) Spanish. (C) French.

input: M: Oh, no! I'm supposed to meet her at seven sharp. What time is it now? W: Six thirty. M: I'd better get ready. W: Where are you going? M: Haven't made up our minds yet. Maybe to a restaurant, or perhaps to the movies first. W: Why don't you go and see Citizen Kane at the Classic Film Festival? It's supposed to be great. M: Oh, maybe we will. Psycho is also playing. I've heard it's really good, too. W: If you like horror films with lots of blood. Personally I don't. Well, I really should be going. Do you want to go swimming tomorrow? M: I'd be glad to, but I might have to go to the studio and do some work. Can I let you know the first thing in the morning? W: Sure. That'll be fine. M: Oh, there's the phone. It must be Tracy. W: Well, I'd better be going then. Have a good time tonight. M: Thanks. I'll ta lk to you tomorrow.
target: When will the man and Tracy meet? (A) At 6:30. (B) At 7:00. (C) At 7:30.

input: M: Will you please change this channel? I can't stand this program. W: If you wait a minute, the news will be on next. I want to be sure to see it tonight.
target: What are these people doing? (A) They are watching TV. (B) They are listening to the radio. (C) They are swimming in the channel.

input: M: Jane, have you met Arvid Brown? I think he is going to your school. W: Oh, that Arvid. I've heard a lot about him. We've never actually been introduced.
target: Does Jane know Arvid Brown? (A) She doesn't know him. (B) She knows something about him. (C) She knows him very well.

input: M: Honey, we have walked for a long time. Do you want to stop for supper? W: Yes, I'm hungry. This restaurant nearby is very popular. M: That sounds fine.
target: Where are the speakers going? (A) A supermarket. (B) A restaurant. (C) A park.

input: W: Jack, why don't you go to work by bike? M: I used to, but the weather today is so nice, and I decide to walk to my company. It's a good way to take exercise though I have to leave home an hour earlier than usual.
target: What does the man want to do? (A) Go to work on foot. (B) Start work earlier than usual. (C) Take exercise in the company.

input: W: I'm leaving for Madrid on business next week. M: Take John's address, in case you have time to drop in on him there.
target: When will the woman leave for Madrid? (A) Next week. (B) This week. (C) The day after tomorrow.

input: M: Which day do you like best, Lily? W: I like weekends, because I don't have to work.
target: Which day does the woman like best? (A) Monday. (B) Wednesday. (C) Saturday.

input: M: How are their talks going on? Have reached any agreement? W: They only seem to have agreed to set another date for further talks.
target: What can we infer from the conversation? (A) The talks haven't started yet. (B) The talks haven't achieved much. (C) The talks have produced a general agreement.

input: M: Are you going home for winter vacation? W: I've agreed to take a part-time job at the school-library.
target: What is the woman going to do during the winter vacation? (A) She is returning for the vacation. (B) She will work in the school library. (C) She will study in the school library.

input: W: Have you found anything wrong with my heart? M: Not yet. I'm still examining. I'll let you know the result tomorrow.
target: What's the relationship between the two speakers? (A) Teacher and student. (B) Doctor and patient. (C) Policeman and traffic law breaker.

input: W: Can I help you, sir? M: Yes, I bought this hat yesterday. Can I change it for a larger one?
target: What does the man want to do? (A) Change the hat (B) Return the hat (C) Buy another hat

input: M: I'm going to the school and I'll pass the supermarket on my way back. Do you need to buy anything,mum? I heard you said there's no coffee at home. W: You father bought it. Please buy a kilo of sugar, two kilos of rice and a pack of tea, Matthew.
target: What shouldn't Matthew buy? (A) Tea. (B) Sugar. (C) Coffee.

input: W: I don't understand how you got a ticket. I always thought you drive carefully. M: I usually am, but I thought I could make it before the light changed.
target: Why did the man receive a ticket? (A) He was speeding. (B) He ran a red light. (C) He went through a stop sign.

input: W: I'd like to go shopping with you this week. When are you usually free? M: I'm usually very busy from Monday to Thursday, but I'm free on Friday.

input: W: David, are you coming with us to the park? M: No, I'm sorry, but I have to catch up with my homework.
